column9: and it seems the some programs wrongly hard code | my home directory when being compiled :-( | for instance : |  | [dude@python dude]$ strings /usr/bin/gentoo | grep dude | /home/dude/ | [dude@python dude]$ strings /usr/bin/xine | grep dude | /home/dude/redhat/tmp/xine-root/usr/share/locale |  | these should probably be considered bugs in the program's build process | (especially for xine
column10: look at that!)
column11: i'll report them upstream if/when i | have some time.  this is a standard trap for people building things from source. it's generally wise to have a special "build" environment to avoid these hassles. most likely you have some library loading path in your env. an strace of the app will show it:   the-app 2&1 | grep dude  personally
column12: i have a script called logbuild whose entire purpose is to start a shell with a minimal build environment
column13: logged with script. the prevents this kind of error. since configure yanks all sorts of ill documented values from one's environment for use in the build (cc
column14: arch
column15: various ld_* variables) this kind of thing is necessary.  often the easiest thing is to have a special nonroot account with no .profile for building stuff.  cheers

column4: ben liblit wrote:   well
column5: i've figured out the problem.  i guess you could say it's an alsa   bug.  when one configures using "--with-cards=all"
column6: alsa blindly turns   on the various config_snd_usb_* macros even if config_usb is not   actually set. [...]  matthias
column7: would you please consider hooking up this patch in your   alsa-driver.spec?  it can be added in the obvious manner:    i suppose i should send this along to the alsa developers as well.  for   them i'll produce a "proper" patch that makes the fix in "acinclude.m4".     or is someone else on this list already part of the alsa developer   community
column8: and willing to shepherd this through for me?  not me
column9: but imho it's kind of offtopic to put it in freshrpms.net rpms.  upstream is the way to go...  --  \/ille skytt  ville.skytta at iki.fi   _______________________________________________ rpm-list mailing list  http://lists.freshrpms.net/mailman/listinfo/rpm-list

column2: if anyone here is running (null) beta then you may like these gnome theme packages. they are enhanced and repackages from my previous theme packs
column3: this time to conform to the way pre-release rh8 handles themes for gtk1 and gtk2.  redhat has a preferences - themes app
column4: but themes only show up there that have both gtk1.2 (gnome1) themes and gtk1.4 (gtk2 aka gnome2) themes available. then rh will apply the theme to both gtk versions
column5: so the user does not really notice that different gtk toolkit versions are being used
column6: since they *should* look the same.  this "gtk2-engines-compat" rpm has gtk2 ported themes for those themes that are included in the rh package "gtk-engines" themes pack for gtk1.  the "gtk1+2-themez" pack mostly repackages my previous theme rpms in a way that the (null) btea like

column2: hi all
column3: i've decided at last to test the alsa sound drivers. as usual the result is that i've spent much more time repackaging the darn thing than actually testing the functionalities or trying to hear the great sound quality people seem to think it outputs... but hey
column4: some of you will benefit from that
column5: right? ;-)  i've got the whole thing working on a valhalla system
column6: but the packages should easily install or at least recompile on enigma
column7: limbo/(null) and maybe others
column8: who knows ;-)  here are quick instructions for those of you that wish to try it out : - recompile the "alsa-driver" source rpm for your running kernel   (you can install the binary package if you're using the i686 2.4.18-10) - install this "alsa-driver" package - install the "alsa-libs" package - install the "alsa-utils" package  now go to this url and find out what you need to change in your /etc/modules.conf file to replace the default oss driver loading : http://www.alsa-project.org/alsa-doc/ (very complete and very good documentation!) hopefully you'll see that your card *is* supported ;-)  reboot
column9: or remove by hand your current sound modules (you'll probably need to stop many applications to free the sound resource...) "by hand" and insert the new ones. if all is well you've got alsa working! ("dmesg" to check is a good idea)
column10: you now just need to adjust the volume levels with e.g. aumix and alsamixer because everything is muted by default.  with "aplay" you can already test files to see if you hear anything. you can also install the xmms plugin (seems to make my xmms segfault on exit... hmmm
column11: but maybe it's another plugin) to listen to your good ol' mp3 files... that's it!  it really isn't complicated
column12: and has never been from what i see. the only thing i disliked was to have to install from source... but as i can't imagine myself doing that ;-) i've repackaged everything cleanly. even the /dev entries are included in the rpm package (and *not* created by an ugly %post script
column13: i insist!) and seamlessly integrate into the /etc/makedev.d structure. there are also a few other noticeable differences with the default provided alsa spec files
column14: for example i've split alsa-lib's development files into an alsa-lib-devel package and included static libraries... there are others of course (oh yes
column15: the kernel version against which the "alsa-driver" package is compiled gets neatly integrated in the rpm release
column16: so does the architecture!).  i'm open to any comments or suggestions about these packages!  download : http://ftp.freshrpms.net/pub/freshrpms/testing/alsa/  current spec files : http://freshrpms.net/builds/alsa-driver/alsa-driver.spec http://freshrpms.net/builds/alsa-lib/alsa-lib.spec http://freshrpms.net/builds/alsa-utils/alsa-utils.spec (all others
column17: patches etc. : http://freshrpms.net/builds/ )  matthias  ps: as an extra bonus
column18: i've also recompiled xine with alsa support! simply run "xine -a alsa09" and off you go! it may even support 5.1 and s/pdif ;-)  --  clean custom red hat linux rpm packages : http://freshrpms.net/ red hat linux release 7.3 (valhalla) running linux kernel 2.4.18-10 load : 0.57 0.42 0.42

column2: blogstart:   **dublin**: something from the archives.    daev walsh forwards an article from the irish digest about ''billy in the bowl''.  this story is also immortalised in an old dublin song
column3: which in turn was mentioned in a pogues track.  billy was a legless beggar in the alleys of stoneybatter and grangegorman (where i now live) during the 18th century
column4: who discovered a new
column5: but not entirely legal
column6: way to make money.  blogend:  linktext: billy in the bowl  from:         daev  subject:      the case of the stoneybatter strangler  a story of my new neighbourhood...   the irish digest july 1964   the case of the stoneybatter strangler  the handsome
column7: deformed billy in the bowl evolved a plan to rob his donors. then
column8: one night
column9: he made the biggest mistake of his life   dublin in the eighteenth century was noted for two things - the architectural beauty of its public buildings and the large number of beggars who sought alms in its maze of streets and lanes.  many of these beggars relied on visitors and the gentry for their coin
column10: but there was one who campaigned among the working class.  this was "billy in the bowl"  the strange appellation was derived from the fact that billy's sole means of transport was a large bowl-shaped car with wheels.  seated in this " bowl "
column11: the beggar would propel himself along by pushing against the ground with wooden plugs
column12: one in each hand.  billy's unusual means of conveyance was vitally necessary
column13: as he had been born without legs.  nature
column14: however
column15: had compensated for this by endowing him with powerful arms and shoulders and
column16: what was most important
column17: an unusually handsome face.  this was billy's greatest asset in his daily routine of separating sympathetic passers-by from their small change.  the cunning young beggar would wait at a convenient spot on one of the many lonely roads or lanes which were a feature of eighteenth century grangegorman and stoneybatter
column18: until a servant girl or an old lady would come along.  he would then put on is most attractive smile which
column19: together with his black curly hair
column20: never failed to halt the females.  the fact that such a handsome young man was so terribly handicapped physically always evoked pity.  "billy in the bowl"
column21: however
column22: wasn't satisfied with becoming the daily owner of a generous number of small coins; what his greed demanded were substantial sums of money.  the more he managed to get the more he could indulge in his pet vices - gambling and drinking.  as a result the beggar evolved a plan to rob unsuspecting sympathisers. the first time lie put his plan into operation was on a cold march evening as dusk
column23: was falling.  the victim was a middle aged woman who was passing through grangegorman lane on her way to visit friends in queen street - on dublin's north quays.  when billy heard the woman's footsteps
column24: he hid behind some bushes in a ditch which skirted the lane.  as his unsuspecting victim drew close
column25: the beggar moaned and shouted
column26: and cried out for help.  trembling with excitement
column27: the woman dashed to the spot where billy lay concealed.  she bent down to help the beggar out of the ditch
column28: when two powerful arms closed around her throat and pulled her into the bushes.  in a few minutes it was all over.  the woman lay in a dead faint
column29: and billy was travelling at a fast rate down the lane in his " bowl "
column30: his victirn's purse snug in his coat pocket.  an hour after the robbery the woman was found in a distracted condition
column31: but failed to give a description of her assailant.  and
column32: as "billy in the bowl" had figured
column33: nobody would suspect a deformed beggar.  again and again the beggar carried out his robbery plan
column34: always shifting the place of attack to a different part of grangegorman or  stoneybatter.  on one occasion " billy in "the bowl " tried his tactics on a sturdy servant girl who put up such a vigorous resistance that he was forced to strangle her.  the incident became known as the 11 grangegorman lane murder and caused a great stir.  hundred.s flocked to the scene of the crime and for a couple of months "billy in the bowl" was forced to desert his usual haunts.  around this period
column35: dublin's first-ever police force was been mobilised
column36: and the first case they were confronted with was the grangegorman lane murder.  months passed and  "billy in the bowl" reverted once again to his old pasttime.  a number of young servant girls were lured into ditches and robbed
column37: and the police were inundated with so many complaints that a nightly patrol was placed on the district.  but the beggar still rolled along in his "bowl" pitied and unsuspected.  then came the night that finished billy's career of crime.  two stoudy built female cooks
column38: trudging back to their places of employment after a night out in the city
column39: were surprised and not a little shocked to hear shouts for help.  rushing over
column40: they came upon a huddled figure in the ditch.  billy
column41: thinking there was only one woman
column42: grabbed one of the cooks and tried to pull her into the ditch.  she proved much too strong for him
column43: however) and while resisting tore 'at his face with her sharp finger-nails.  meanwhile
column44: her companion acted with speed and daring.  pulling out her large hatpin she made .for the beggar
column45: and plunged the pin into his right eye.  the screams and howls of the wounded beggar reverberated throughout the district and brought people dashing to the scene.  among them was a member of the nightly police patrol who promptly arrested the groaning billy.  "billy in the bowl" was tried and sentenced for robbery with violence
column46: but they could never prove it was he who had strangled the servant girl.  the grangegorman-stoneybatter district became once again a quiet
column47: attractive dublin suburb where old ladies strolled
column48: and carefree servant girls laughed and giggled as they wended their way home at night.    daev  _______________________________ rev.  dave 'daev' walsh

column2: ---------- forwarded message ---------- from: vernon schryver  to: dcc@calcite.rhyolite.com date: mon
column3: 26 aug 2002 09:09:05 -0600 (mdt) subject: version 1.1.11 of the dcc  ersion 1.1.11 of the dcc source is in http://www.rhyolite.com/anti-spam/dcc/source/dccd.tar.z and http://www.dcc-servers.net/dcc/source/dccd.tar.z  http://www.rhyolite.com/anti-spam/dcc/dcc-tree/changes and http://www.dcc-servers.net/dcc/dcc-tree/changes start with      fix dccm bugs with handling a non-responsive server.     change misc/hackmc to modify sendmail.cf to reject unauthorized relay  attempts with a temporary failure when they are supposed to be sent  to the dcc but dccm is not running.  this prevents leaking relay  relay spam.  you must use the new hackmc script to install this  change in sendmail.cf.     remove "# whitelisted" from `cdcc stats` output to give more room  for totals.     prevent empty dccproc log files as noted by krzysztof snopek.     even fatal errors should cause dccproc to exit with 0 to avoid  rejecting mail
column4: as noted by krzysztof snopek.     when server hostnames have common ip addresses
column5: prefer the server  with the non-anonymous client-id
column6: noted by krzysztof snopek.   vernon schryver    vjs@rhyolite.com _______________________________________________ dcc mailing list      dcc@rhyolite.com http://www.rhyolite.com/mailman/listinfo/dcc    ------------------------------------------------------- this sf.net email is sponsored by: osdn - tired of that same old cell phone?  get a new here for free! https://www.inphonic.com/r.asp?r=sourceforge1&refcode1=vs3390 _______________________________________________ spamassassin-talk mailing list spamassassin-talk@lists.sourceforge.net https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/spamassassin-talk

column2: there is a whitelist rbl now!  ironport's bonded sender is  basically a whitelist rbl where you post a bond to get on the  list
column3: and then lose the bond if you end up spamming from that ip  address (or something like that).  http://www.bondedsender.org/  c  on sunday
column4: august 25
column6: at 07:58  pm
column7: bart schaefer wrote:   4. dnsbl: only certifies an ip address
column8: not who is using it. as it is  currently used
column9: dnsbl allows you to look up if some ip address   has been  blacklisted by someone. what i haven't seen is a service that   provides a  dns based whitelist.   there's a practical reason for that:  any dns list (white or   black) works  only for a limited number of ips; the set of unlisted ips is   much larger  than the set in the dns list.  if you have to make a binary decision to  accept or reject
column10: you'll be wrong less often if you reject the   blacklist  and accept everything else
column11: rather than accept the whitelist and reject  everything else.   a whitelist is only helpful when (a) you only want mail from a limited  number of known sources
column12: or (b) you can use a secondary system   like sa to  decide what to do with the vast unlisted masses.  most mtas still make  only the binary decision
column13: because the secondary computation is   expensive.   with sa's cooperation
column14: though
column15: it might be worth a try.  even better if  one could get commercial anti-spam outfits to agree to factor it in.    ------------------------------------------------------- this sf.net email is sponsored by: osdn - tired of that same old cell phone?  get a new here for free! https://www.inphonic.com/r.asp?r=sourceforge1&refcode1=vs3390 _______________________________________________ spamassassin-talk mailing list spamassassin-talk@lists.sourceforge.net https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/spamassassin-talk

column2: jm@jmason.org (justin mason) writes:   actually
column3: i want to avoid that -- i've already removed spamproxyd  from the distro for 2.40. here's why:    when they're in the distro
column4: *we* have to support them -- which is  not necessarily a good thing when we didn't write them in the first  place
column5: or when the coder in question may not *want* us to maintain  them. :(  i would be in favor of creating new spamassassin cvs modules and bugzilla categories for other clients (provided there is sufficient interest and a maintainer).  dan

column2: i would be in favor of creating new spamassassin cvs modules and  bugzilla categories for other clients (provided there is sufficient  interest and a maintainer).  yeah
column3: i'd be with that -- as long as they have a maintainer ;)  however regarding cvs
column4: i'd say many projects might find it easier to just sign up as a new proj with sf.net -- it might save them having to go through us (not sure
column5: depends on what sf.net's procedures are like).  --j.

column2: on wed
column3: aug 28
column5: justin mason wrote:  actually
column6: i think procmail supports this directly. use dropprivs=yes  at the top of the /etc/procmailrc.  hey
column7: look at that!         dropprivs   if  set  to `yes'  procmail  will drop all privileges      it might have had (suid or sgid).  this is only      useful if you want to guarantee that the bottom half      of  the /etc/procmailrc file is executed on behalf      of the recipient.  of course
column8: removing setuid/gid bits on programs that don't need it is always a good idea.  a general rule of system administration: don't give out permissions unless you absolutely need to.   ;)  --  randomly generated tagline: "the cardinal rule at our school is simple. no shooting at teachers. if  you have to shoot a gun
column9: shoot it at a student or an administrator."                  - "word smart ii"
column10: from princeton review pub.

column2: well if you're talking about epiphany
column3: which is in january
column4: then yes it is 5 months.some people do celebrate christmas on january 6th
column5: or even the 13th.  but i am certain that what you are thinking is the correct thought.  please don't flame me. just trying to be humerous =)   matt kettler said:  on an unrelated
column6: but similarly amusing note
column7: a spam i received (and was   tagged by sa) today began with:     i bet you haven't even realized that christmas is just 5 months away
column8: did you?    strangely
column9: no i wasn't aware that christmas was 5 months away. here in  the  us christmas is a bit less than 4 months away. where exactly is  the  "international month line" anyway? i've never seen the -74400  timezone  before

column2: justin mason wrote:  phil r lawrence said:     something to watch out for is to use "nomime" = 1 in the mail::audit ctor; the m:a folks changed the api there.  what has mime to do with it?  i read in perldoc m:a that your suggestion  is less expensive
column3: but how does that help s:a?      m:a
column4: for some reason
column5: changes its base class depending on whether the  incoming message is mime or not.  therefore the mail::internet methods  suddenly become unavailable for mime messages...    (you do *not* want to know what i thought of that when i found it ;)  as a new user of sa
column6: i guess i'm having trouble connecting the dots.  if  i understand you:  if i don't use the "nomime" = 1 option and i recieve  mime mail
column7: the mail::internet modules become unavailable.  unavailable for which?  ma?  sa?  what do these methods do?  does this  mean my incoming mime mail won't be checked by sa unless i specify  "nomime" = 1?  thanks
column8: phil

column2: -----begin pgp signed message----- hash: sha1  i may be dense
column3: but why would anyone want to utilize habeus?  to me
column4: it looks  like a potential backdoor to anyone's defenses against spam.  if i were a spammer
column5: i'd simply set up a server
column6: send out my spam with the  habeus headers and continue till i was reasonably certain i'd been reported.   then i'd simply reconfigure the server and reconnect to a different ip.  as  long as no one can establish my connection to the web sites my spam is  directing people to
column7: i'm home free.  since i can set up spamassassin to i don't "lose" any email
column8: what do i gain  by making it easier for spam to get through?? - --  - ------------------------------------------------------------------------ robin lynn frank---director of operations---paradigm

i may be dense
column3: but why would anyone want to utilize habeus?  to  me
column4: it looks like a potential backdoor to anyone's defenses against spam.  you're not dense. i'm going to zero the habeas scores on my copy of spamassassin. i think they were added to sa quite prematurely. to me it's simple:  1. people who send me legitimate email have absolutely no motivation to use habeas
column5: at least until it gets lots more press
column6: and even then only bulk-mailing companies like amazon or ebay are going to bother
column7: and i already whitelist them. individuals won't bother.  2. spammers have lots of motivation to forge the habeas headers
column8: and a good percentage of them are completely out of the legal reach of habeas.  i think it should be subjected to the same testing and scrutiny as any other potential new rule. when i test against my corpus here's what i get:  overall     spam  nonspam     s/o   score  name   13851     8919     4932    0.64    0.00  (all messages)       0        0        0    0.00   -1.00  habeas_swe  the score of -1.0 is pretty harmless right now
column9: but it still looks like a useless rule so far.  -- michael moncur  mgm at starlingtech.com  http://www.starlingtech.com/ "never interrupt your enemy when he is making a mistake." --napoleon    ------------------------------------------------------- this sf.net email is sponsored by: jabber - the world's fastest growing  real-time communications platform! don't just im. build it in!  http://www.jabber.com/osdn/xim _______________________________________________ spamassassin-talk mailing list spamassassin-talk@lists.sourceforge.net https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/spamassassin-talk

column2: on wednesday
column3: august 28
column5: at 11:48  am
column6: robin lynn frank wrote:   if i were a spammer
column7: i'd simply set up a server
column8: send out my   spam with the  habeus headers and continue till i was reasonably certain i'd   been reported.  then i'd simply reconfigure the server and reconnect to a   different ip.  as  long as no one can establish my connection to the web sites my spam is  directing people to
column9: i'm home free.  uh... the reason is simple. habeas runs something called the  "habeas infringers list"
column10: and if you use their trademark without  their permission
column11: you'll end up on it.  then
column12: when you send spam  with the misappropriated header
column13: users of sa (2.40 supports  this) will tag your mail as spam
column14: rather than let it through.  this may be done independantly of your ip address
column15: so be  prepared to constantly change domain names
column16: and move your  servers as fast as you send spam.  also
column17: that little haiku is a copyrighted work
column18: so not only can  habeas sue
column19: they must sue to protect their copyright. and since  it's a trademark as well
column20: that's a double-whammy. habeas has  some pretty high-powered legal people
column21: who will gladly go to  town on violators.  the whole point here is to give them the legal leverage they  need to put spammers out of business
column22: and not only block mail  from them
column23: but allow through the things that really aren't spam.  --b    ------------------------------------------------------- this sf.net email is sponsored by: jabber - the world's fastest growing  real-time communications platform! don't just im. build it in!  http://www.jabber.com/osdn/xim _______________________________________________ spamassassin-talk mailing list spamassassin-talk@lists.sourceforge.net https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/spamassassin-talk

column2: robin lynn frank  writes:   i may be dense
column3: but why would anyone want to utilize habeus?  to me
column4: it looks like a potential backdoor to anyone's defenses against spam.   if i were a spammer
column5: i'd simply set up a server
column6: send out my spam with  the habeus headers and continue till i was reasonably certain i'd been  reported.  then i'd simply reconfigure the server and reconnect to a  different ip.  as long as no one can establish my connection to the  web sites my spam is directing people to
column7: i'm home free.  here is the bug i opened:    http://www.hughes-family.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=762  rbls have the same problem
column8: but there is no negative rbl header rule with a -20 score that can be forged
column9: so the problem is unique to habeas.   since i can set up spamassassin to i don't "lose" any email
column10: what do i  gain by making it easier for spam to get through??  my primary issue is the magnitude of the negative score and that it was not determined empirically.  i am also concerned that it was added after the rules freeze
column11: that such a major change was not discussed in advance
column12: etc.  there's also no evidence that the rule will actually reduce fps.  people who are smart enough to use the rule are probably capable of writing email that doesn't look like spam (i'm not counting spam mailing lists which you need to be exempted from spam filtering).  dan   ------------------------------------------------------- this sf.net email is sponsored by: jabber - the world's fastest growing  real-time communications platform! don't just im. build it in!  http://www.jabber.com/osdn/xim _______________________________________________ spamassassin-talk mailing list spamassassin-talk@lists.sourceforge.net https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/spamassassin-talk

column2: msg_id_added_by_mta   (4.0 points)  invalid_msgid         (1.8 points)   msg_id_added_by_mta_2 (1.6 points)  here are the new scores in the 2.40 branch (they may change
column3: but they are better than before).  score invalid_msgid                  1.226 score msg_id_added_by_mta            1.696 score msg_id_added_by_mta_2          0.532  total of 3.5 which is better than 7.4
column4: i suppose.  if they fixed their msgid
column5: it would help.  i suppose we could allow comments without hurting spam detection too much
column6: but i'm reluctant (it's pretty bizarre to put a comment after the message-id header).  can you open a bugzilla ticket for this one?  dan   ------------------------------------------------------- this sf.net email is sponsored by: jabber - the world's fastest growing  real-time communications platform! don't just im. build it in!  http://www.jabber.com/osdn/xim _______________________________________________ spamassassin-talk mailing list spamassassin-talk@lists.sourceforge.net https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/spamassassin-talk

column2: on wednesday 28 august 2002 01:50 pm
column3: robin lynn frank wrote:   on wednesday 28 august 2002 01:34 pm
column4: brian mcnett wrote:   also
column5: that little haiku is a copyrighted work
column6: so not only can   habeas sue
column7: they must sue to protect their copyright. and since   it's a trademark as well
column8: that's a double-whammy. habeas has   some pretty high-powered legal people
column9: who will gladly go to   town on violators.    the whole point here is to give them the legal leverage they   need to put spammers out of business
column10: and not only block mail   from them
column11: but allow through the things that really aren't spam.   and if a spammer forges headers???  there must be *some* way of tracking a spammer down
column12: since they are planning  on making money from the spam.  what a court would consider evidence of being  the spammer is another question.  --  give a man a match
column13: and he'll be warm for a minute
column14: but set him on fire
column15: and he'll be warm for the rest of his life.  icq: 132152059 | advanced spam filtering software: http://spamassassin.org   ------------------------------------------------------- this sf.net email is sponsored by: jabber - the world's fastest growing  real-time communications platform! don't just im. build it in!  http://www.jabber.com/osdn/xim _______________________________________________ spamassassin-talk mailing list spamassassin-talk@lists.sourceforge.net https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/spamassassin-talk

column2: on wed
column4: matthew cline wrote:   there must be *some* way of tracking a spammer down
column5: since they are  planning on making money from the spam.  many spammers make money not from response to the spam
column6: but from selling the service of spamming on behalf of someone else.  you might track down whoever paid for the mailing
column7: but tracking down the actual sender might be more difficult
column8: and even if they manage to recover damages from the buyer they haven't stopped the spammer
column9: so the benefit is strictly to habeas
column10: not to the recipients of the spam.  that's the main problem i have with the whole scenario: my pain
column11: habeas's gain
column12: and those most likely to be held liable are those least likely to be the really serious abusers.    ------------------------------------------------------- this sf.net email is sponsored by: jabber - the world's fastest growing  real-time communications platform! don't just im. build it in!  http://www.jabber.com/osdn/xim _______________________________________________ spamassassin-talk mailing list spamassassin-talk@lists.sourceforge.net https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/spamassassin-talk

column2: matthew cline  writes:   there must be *some* way of tracking a spammer down
column3: since they are  planning on making money from the spam.  what a court would consider  evidence of being the spammer is another question.  haha!!!  just a few notes:   - it will be difficult to find
column4: prosecute
column5: and win money from someone    in various non-friendly countries where spam originates (china is a    good example) even if they do officially "respect" copyright law.   - law suits take time. between now and conclusion of the first court    case
column6: we could have years of spam in our mail boxes!   - contact information can change: phone numbers
column7: po boxes
column8: stolen    cell phones
column9: temporary email addresses
column10: etc.   - spammers do not always remember to include contact information!  i    don't understand it either
column11: but nobody said they were bright.  also
column12: some spam is non-commercial or sent by a third-party (for example
column13: "pump and dump" stock scams)
column14: so contact information is not strictly    required for the spammer to get their way.  dan   ------------------------------------------------------- this sf.net email is sponsored by: jabber - the world's fastest growing  real-time communications platform! don't just im. build it in!  http://www.jabber.com/osdn/xim _______________________________________________ spamassassin-talk mailing list spamassassin-talk@lists.sourceforge.net https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/spamassassin-talk

column6: robin lynn frank wrote:   and if a spammer forges headers???  header forgeries are trivially easy to detect. the main way that  spammers hide their originating ips is not by forging headers
column7: but by sending through open proxy servers.  it used to be that  spammers used open relay mailserver
column8: but these often betray the  originating ip
column9: and the proliferation of open relay blocklists
column10: and the introduction of port 25 blocking on the part of many  isps make open relays unattractive to spammers.  one would think
column11: that the combination of a forged habeas-swe
column12: and mail sent through an anonymizing open proxy would be a  fairly good indication of spam.  tracking a spammer to his  meatspace location is not as difficult as you might think
column13: once  you have legal recourse to subpoena records.  --b    ------------------------------------------------------- this sf.net email is sponsored by: jabber - the world's fastest growing  real-time communications platform! don't just im. build it in!  http://www.jabber.com/osdn/xim _______________________________________________ spamassassin-talk mailing list spamassassin-talk@lists.sourceforge.net https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/spamassassin-talk

column2: guys
column3: the habeas infringers list (hil) exists explicitly to deal with spammers while we're getting judgments against them and especially in other countries
column4: where those judgments are harder to get.  please note that nobody has ever had an incentive before to go after regular spammers.  yes
column5: some attorneys general have prosecuted blatant pyramid schemes
column6: and isps have won some theft of service suits
column7: but the vast majority of spammers go forward with out any legal hassles.  so
column8: i can't understand how daniel can assert that you can't track spammers down when it's never really been tried.  we can subpoena the records of the business they spammed on behalf of.  we can subpoena the records of the isp that provided them service
column9: and of the credit card they used for the whack-a-mole accounts.  we can use private investigators.  yes
column10: these people are often lowlifes (chickenboners).  but
column11: they're not secret agents.  they're just trying to make a buck
column12: and habeas' whole business is about finding them and putting them out of business  habeas has the incentive to pursue spammers (that use our warrant mark) in a way that no one ever has had before.  given that our whole business plan relies on habeas becoming synonymous with "not spam"
column13: i can't understand why you would assume ahead of time that we will be unsuccessful
column14: plan for that failure
column15: and in so doing
column16: remove the potential of success
column17: which is anti-spam filters like sa acting on the habeas warrant mark.  daniel
column18: it's easy enough for you to change the habeas scores yourself on your installation.  if habeas fails to live up to its promise to only license the warrant mark to non-spammers and to place all violators on the hil
column19: then i have no doubt that justin and craig will quickly remove us from the next release.  but
column20: you're trying to kill habeas before it has a chance to show any promise.  at the end of the day
column21: spamassassin is like the club
column22: in that it encourages thieves (spammers) to just go after the next car (those without sa) rather than yours.  habeas can play the role of lojack (the transmitter)
column23: in enabling the apprehension of thieves so that they don't steal any more cars.  but only if we're given a chance to succeed.            - dan -- dan kohn       -----original message----- from: daniel quinlan [mailto:quinlan@pathname.com]  sent: wednesday

danq i think it would make more sense to start habeas with a less     danq aggressive score (one which will not give spammers a quick path     danq into everyone's inbox) and after we've seen evidence that the     danq system works
column3: then we can increase the magnitude of the score.  better yet
column4: let the ga figure out the correct score. ;-) that will obviously take awhile since you'll have to acquire enough messages with it
column5: but it should give you a good idea if the presence of habeus headers are good spam indicators or not.  if they are
column6: my guess is that habeus will probably not succeed.  taking things further off-topic: does habeus charge a license fee to organizations who want to use their copyrighted material or is their sole revenue stream to come from legal judgements?  on the one hand
column7: if they charge license fees
column8: i'd worry that when times got tough they'd be somewhat less critical of organizations we'd call spammers today in order to generate license fees.  if not
column9: i'd worry the pendulum would swing the other way and they'd go after legitimate businesses in an attempt to generate more revenues from judgements and/or out of court settlements.  either way
column10: it seems like they have an interesting tightrope to walk.  --  skip montanaro skip@pobox.com consulting: http://manatee.mojam.com/~skip/resume.html   ------------------------------------------------------- this sf.net email is sponsored by:thinkgeek welcome to geek heaven. http://thinkgeek.com/sf _______________________________________________ spamassassin-talk mailing list spamassassin-talk@lists.sourceforge.net https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/spamassassin-talk

column2: dan kohn  writes:   guys
column3: the habeas infringers list (hil) exists explicitly to deal with  spammers while we're getting judgments against them and especially in  other countries
column4: where those judgments are harder to get.  my concern doesn't stem from failing to understand how your business is intended to work.  my concern is the lack of empirical evidence that it will reduce the amount of uncaught spam.   please note that nobody has ever had an incentive before to go after  regular spammers.  yes
column5: some attorneys general have prosecuted blatant  pyramid schemes
column6: and isps have won some theft of service suits
column7: but  the vast majority of spammers go forward with out any legal hassles.  so
column8: i can't understand how daniel can assert that you can't track  spammers down when it's never really been tried.  please don't misquote me.  i did not assert that you "can't track spammers".  here is what i said:  | it will be difficult to find
column9: prosecute
column10: and win money from someone in | various non-friendly countries where spam originates (china is a good | example) even if they do officially "respect" copyright law.  i understand the incentive that you have to pursue spammers
column11: but that does not directly translate to less spam being sent to my inbox.  it is an indirect effect and the magnitude of the effect may not be sufficient to counteract the ease with which a -20 score on the mark allows spam to avoid being tagged as spam.   daniel
column12: it's easy enough for you to change the habeas scores yourself  on your installation.  if habeas fails to live up to its promise to  only license the warrant mark to non-spammers and to place all  violators on the hil
column13: then i have no doubt that justin and craig will  quickly remove us from the next release.  but
column14: you're trying to kill  habeas before it has a chance to show any promise.  i think i've worked on sa enough to understand that i can localize a score.  i'm just not comfortable with using spamassassin as a vehicle for drumming up your business at the expense of our user base.  i think it would make more sense to start habeas with a less aggressive score (one which will not give spammers a quick path into everyone's inbox) and after we've seen evidence that the system works
column15: then we can increase the magnitude of the score.  dan   ------------------------------------------------------- this sf.net email is sponsored by:thinkgeek welcome to geek heaven. http://thinkgeek.com/sf _______________________________________________ spamassassin-talk mailing list spamassassin-talk@lists.sourceforge.net https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/spamassassin-talk

column2: i think i've worked on sa enough to understand that i can localize a  score.  i'm just not comfortable with using spamassassin as a vehicle  for drumming up your business at the expense of our user base.  this is exactly what i think. spamassassin has always been conservative about adding unproven rbls and such
column3: and this should be the same.   i think it would make more sense to start habeas with a less aggressive  score (one which will not give spammers a quick path into everyone's  inbox) and after we've seen evidence that the system works
column4: then we can  increase the magnitude of the score.  i say start it with a zero score and put it in 70_cvs_rules_under_test like any other unproven rule. then score it based on actual results
column5: not promises. my corpus does not yet contain a single non-spam (or spam) message with a habeas mark. based on that
column6: it doesn't impress me and it wouldn't impress the ga either. rules with exactly the same statistics are being dropped from sa right now
column7: and i don't see why this should be any different.  -- michael moncur  mgm at starlingtech.com  http://www.starlingtech.com/ "furious activity is no substitute for understanding." --h. h. williams    ------------------------------------------------------- this sf.net email is sponsored by:thinkgeek welcome to geek heaven. http://thinkgeek.com/sf _______________________________________________ spamassassin-talk mailing list spamassassin-talk@lists.sourceforge.net https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/spamassassin-talk

column2: bart schaefer said:   this is off the topic of the rest of this discussion
column3: but amavisd (in all  its incarnations) and mimedefang and several other mta plugins all reject  at smtp time messages that scores higher than some threshold (often 10).    argh
column4: they do not
column5: do they?   the fps must be just gigantic :(   if some new release were to start scoring all spam no higher than 5.1
column6: there'd better be _zero_ fps
column7: because all those filters would drop their  thresholds to 5.  well
column8: my point is more that we should aim our rescoring algorithm so that a spam hits 5.0.    any higher does us no good
column9: as it means an fp is a lot harder to recover from
column10: using compensation rules.  spams *will* hit higher than that -- that's just the way the scoring works. but for our code to be effective
column11: and spread the range of scores correctly
column12: we just have to optimise to hit 1 threshold.  --j.   ------------------------------------------------------- this sf.net email is sponsored by:thinkgeek welcome to geek heaven. http://thinkgeek.com/sf _______________________________________________ spamassassin-talk mailing list spamassassin-talk@lists.sourceforge.net https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/spamassassin-talk

column3: my point is more that we should aim our rescoring algorithm so that  a spam hits 5.0.    any higher does us no good
column4: as it means an fp is  a lot harder to recover from
column5: using compensation rules.  agreed.  but i have always thought that the value 5 was not the best value.  it should have been 0.  i understand that initially only spammy scores were included.  but i believe the algorithm should be purely symmetrical and non-spammy negative values should also have been balancing out the spammy positive values
column6: like they do in sa today. then anything that was positive would be spam and anything negative would be non-spam.  (and i guess exactly zero is grey. :-) today's choice of 5 just adds an offset.  which i think cause people to assume things work differently than they do.  bob

column2: jm@jmason.org (justin mason) writes:   btw i tried tweaking some of the scores that lint-rules complained about  being negative when they shouldn't be
column3: and it *ruined* the results.  it's  worth hand-tweaking a bit
column4: but in some cases
column5: there's counter-intuitive  combinatorial effects like the above
column6: so be careful when tweaking; run  a "./logs-to-c && ./evolve -c" to check the new hitrates afterwards.  my tendency is to say that we shouldn't tweak at all.  - dan

column2: daniel quinlan wrote:  dq before we release
column3: it'd be great if someone could test a few dq additional score ranges.  maybe we can lower fps a bit more.  :-)  i don't think there's much more room for lowering fps left which the ga can  achieve.  remember
column4: also
column5: that the awl will reduce fps
column6: but its effects aren't  factored in to the ga scores.  the work currently being done on the ga
column7: and comparing different methods of  doing the score-setting
column8: is very worthwhile
column9: and extremely useful; however
column10: we  really ought to get a release out
column11: since 2.31 is getting decreasingly useful as  time goes on.  the fp/fn rate of 2.40 with pretty well *any* score-setting mechanism will be  better than 2.31 -- we can continue with adjusting how the scores are set on the  2.41 or 2.50 branches.  dq something like: dq  dq   for (low = -12; low      for (high = 2; high        evolve  you could just allow low and high to be evolved by the ga (within ranges); i'd  be enormously surprised if it didn't end up with low=-12 and high=+6
column12: since  that'd give the ga the broadest lattitude in setting individual scores.  the  issue with fixing low and high is not one of optimization
column13: but rather one of  human-based concern that individual scores larger than about +4 are dangerous  and liable to generate fps
column14: and individual scores less than -8 are dangerous and  liable to be forged to generate fns.  dq maybe even add a nybias loop.  adding an nybias loop is not worthwhile -- changing nybias scores will just  alter the evaluation function's idea of what the fp:fn ratio should be.  dq  afaik there's nothing major hanging out waiting to be checked in  dq  on b2_4_0 is there? dq  dq nope.  great!  dq  i'll be on im most of today
column15: tomorrow
column16: and monday while cranking  dq  on the next deersoft product release (should be a fun one).  hit  dq  me at: dq   dq  aim: hugh3scr dq  icq: 1130120 dq  msn: craig@stanfordalumni.org dq  yim: hughescr dq  dq we've been hanging out on irc at irc.rhizomatic.net on #spamassassin dq (the timezone difference gets in the way
column17: though).  i've been searching for that

column2: if you need to store a database password
column3: then clearly the first step is to store the text outside the web tree.  you can encrypt it and store the encryption key elsewhere
column4: so that at least an attacker has to get two different things. also
column5: don't get full privileges - create a user account that is granted very limited access.  however
column6: you can often do better than this if security is critical.  create a separate program which has these database keys (as noted above)
column7: and make the web program contact it.  create a very limited protocol that only lets you do the operations you need (you can add specific operations later).  there's a performance hit
column8: which you're trading for improved data isolation.    giorgio zoppi wrote:   on fri
column9: aug 23
column11: david wheeler wrote:     the standard way to store passwords is... not to store passwords.  instead
column12: store a salted hash of the password in a database.  when you get a purported password
column13: you re-salt it
column14: compute the hash
column15: and determine if they are the same.  this is how unix has done it for years.  you want bigger hashes and salts than the old unix systems
column16: and you still want to prevent reading from those files (to foil password crackers). more info is in my book at:    http://www.dwheeler.com/secure-programs     well...but this cannot be applied to database password
column17: which most  web apps use. the only solution i figure is store in clear outside web  tree
column18: any other ideas feasible?    ciao
column19: giorgio.    --  never is forever - deneb@penguin.it  homepage: http://www.cli.di.unipi.it/~zoppi/index.html  --         --   --- david a. wheeler      dwheeler@ida.org

column2: -----begin pgp signed message----- hash: sha1   hi
column3: i am wondering if there are any techniques to make a cd-key of the like  unbreakable.  either by giving it a cancelation date and a periodic renewal  from a server or just by using self md5 signature on the resulting  executable.  i know it must not be easy because the whole software piracy  problem would be resolved but there must be some way to make it really hard  to break it.  anyone have hints on this issue ?  thanks  - --  yannick gingras network programer esc:wq -----begin pgp signature----- version: gnupg v1.0.6 (gnu/linux) comment: for info see http://www.gnupg.org  id8dbqe9bpyzuv7g0dnfo+qraqbhakchtekxwd8zdmwf+okakjxnnpknwacgtxz7 v3bbabue0vx/uy86fhn9ifs= =uwqj -----end pgp signature-----

column4: you'll want to peruse fravia's web site on reverse engineering (and other  things) http://www.woodmann.com/fravia/protec.htm. that specific page  covers just your concerns.   josh  thanks for the input.  some of the tips are quite portable but are there any  special attentions to take when implementing such shemes on a unix system ?  thanks.  - --  yannick gingras coder for obb : ostentatiously breathless brother-in-law http://openbeatbox.org -----begin pgp signature----- version: gnupg v1.0.6 (gnu/linux) comment: for info see http://www.gnupg.org  id8dbqe9dq6guv7g0dnfo+qrapsxakcjd98fovvljet3x9extihruvt7kacenayd wdzlxjxjdmlfhnrn97cd73m= =4clx -----end pgp signature-----

column2: -----begin pgp signed message----- hash: sha1   what do you mean by "cd-key or the like" (i presume that "of" was a  typo)? and what do you mean by "unbreakable"?  "of" was a typo  unbreakable would mean here that no one
column3: even previously authorised entity
column4: could use the system without paying the periodic subscription fee.   you need to be far more explicit about the problem which you wish to  solve
column5: and about the constraints involved.  it could be an online system that work 95% offline but poll frequently an  offsite server.  no mass production cds
column6: maybe mass personalised d/l like sun  jdk.  nothing is fixed yet
column7: we are looking at the way a software can be protected  from unauthorized utilisation.    is the use of "trusted hardware" really worth it ?  does it really make it  more secure ?  look at the dvds.  - --  yannick gingras coder for obb : obdurately buteonine bellwether http://openbeatbox.org -----begin pgp signature----- version: gnupg v1.0.6 (gnu/linux) comment: for info see http://www.gnupg.org  id8dbqe9drrnuv7g0dnfo+qrak8nakclahtmyrugp3ko+dejcvj0mqfjzacgwqvo wz6/cmua23hcmzvycd7xd1q= =v2g8 -----end pgp signature-----

column2: yannick gingras wrote:      i am wondering if there are any techniques to make a cd-key of the like   unbreakable.  either by giving it a cancelation date and a periodic renewal   from a server or just by using self md5 signature on the resulting   executable.  i know it must not be easy because the whole software piracy   problem would be resolved but there must be some way to make it really hard   to break it.  anyone have hints on this issue ?  what do you mean by "cd-key or the like" (i presume that "of" was a typo)? and what do you mean by "unbreakable"?  you need to be far more explicit about the problem which you wish to solve
column3: and about the constraints involved.  some general points:  1. for a conventional "cd key" system
column4: where the actual cds are mass-produced (where you have many identical cds)
column5: and the entire system has to work offline
column6: you cannot solve the problem of valid keys being "traded" (e.g. included along with bootleg copies of the product).  if there's an online element involved
column7: you can "tie" keys to a specific hardware configuration
column8: as is done (afaik) for windows xp's "product activation".  2. anything which uses a symmetric cipher (or hash) is bound to be vulnerable to reverse engineering of the validation routines within the executable.  3. ultimately
column9: any software mechanism will be vulnerable to "cracking"
column10: i.e. modifying the software to disable or circumvent the validation checks.  this can only be prevented by the use of trusted hardware (e.g. a palladium-style system).  most significantly
column11: the data must be supplied in a form which is only accessible by that hardware. if anyone can get at the data in a meaningful (i.e. unencrypted) form
column12: they can extract the useful parts and discard the rest (i.e. any associated protection mechanisms).  iow
column13: you have to "keep the genie in the bottle" at all times. if the data can be got at just once (even if it requires the use of dedicated hardware such as a bus analyser)
column14: it can then be duplicated and distributed without limit.  --  glynn clements

column2: yannick gingras wrote:    what do you mean by "cd-key or the like" (i presume that "of" was a   typo)? and what do you mean by "unbreakable"?    "of" was a typo    unbreakable would mean here that no one
column3: even previously authorised entity
column4: could use the system without paying the periodic subscription fee.     you need to be far more explicit about the problem which you wish to   solve
column5: and about the constraints involved.    it could be an online system that work 95% offline but poll frequently an   offsite server.  no mass production cds
column6: maybe mass personalised d/l like sun   jdk.    nothing is fixed yet
column7: we are looking at the way a software can be protected   from unauthorized utilisation.      is the use of "trusted hardware" really worth it ?  answering that requires fairly complete knowledge of the business model. but
column8: in all probability: no
column9: it isn't usually worth it. so
column10: it comes down to how difficult you want to make the cracker's job.  if the product requires occasional authentication
column11: simple copying won't work; the product has to be cracked. in which case
column12: the issue is whether you're actually going to enter into battle with the crackers
column13: or just make sure that it isn't trivial.  a lot of it comes down to your customer base. teenage kids tend to be more concerned about cost and less concerned about viruses/trojans
column14: and so more willing to use warez. fortune-500 corporations are likely to view matters differently.   does it really make it more secure ?  yes; software techniques will only get you so far. actually
column15: the same is ultimately true for hardware
column16: but cracking hardware is likely to require resources other than just labour.  almost (?) anything can be reverse engineered. but it may be possible to ensure that doing so is uneconomical.   look at the dvds.  iirc
column17: css was cracked by reverse-engineering a software player; and one where the developers forgot to encrypt the decryption key at that.  --  glynn clements

column2: is the use of "trusted hardware" really worth it ?   answering that requires fairly complete knowledge of the business  model. but
column3: in all probability: no
column4: it isn't usually worth it. so
column5: it  comes down to how difficult you want to make the cracker's job.    look at the dvds.   iirc
column6: css was cracked by reverse-engineering a software player; and  one where the developers forgot to encrypt the decryption key at that.  this make me wonder about the relative protection of smart cards.  they have  an internal procession unit around 4mhz.  can we consider them as trusted  hardware ?  the ability to ship smart cards periodicaly uppon cashing of a  monthly subscription fee would not raise too much the cost of "renting" the  system.  smart card do their own self encryption.  can they be used to  decrypt data needed by the system ?  the input of the system could me mangled  and the would keep a reference of how long it was in service.  this sounds really feasible but i may be totaly wrong.  i may also be wrong  about the safety of a smart card.    what do you think ?  --  yannick gingras coder for obb : oceangoing bared bonanza http://openbeatbox.org

column2: software vendors have been trying since forever to prevent software piracy.  remember when you had to enter a specific word from a specific page of the  software manual
column3: which was printed on dark maroon paper so that it could  not be photocopied?  didn't work.  propritery encoding of dvd's?  didn't  work. software that required the use of a registration key?  didn't work.   windows xp was shipped with this supposedly revolutionary method for  stopping piracy
column4: and what happened?  how long was it before the code was  cracked? how many keygens are there for windows xp?  is someone running a  pirated version of xp really going to use windows update to installed a  service pack which breaks their os?  just because m$ didn't include the  change in their readme?  fat chance.  my problem is not the same as ms's one
column5: i don't have to deal with millions of  identical copy of the same cd with propably millions of working keys.  each  download can be unique with a small preparation delay.  the key generator is  a problem only if multiple keys are usable.  if the end users are teenagers
column6: you'll face a huge wall when asking to be 100% of the time online but if we  think of something like a health care system that keep track of patients  personnal information
column7: the end user will be willing to take every possible  steps to protect the system from his own employees to use illegaly.  i agree with all of you that mass production cds will not be safe from piracy  in a near futur.  that can be seen as a collateral of mass market  penetration.  btw thanks for all of you who provided interestiong insight.  i'm playing with  gdb's dissassembler now but i don't think it's what a typical cracker would  use.  any hints on unix cracking tools ?  thanks.  --  yannick gingras coder for obb : onside brainsick bract http://openbeatbox.org

column2: yannick gingras wrote:  is the use of "trusted hardware" really worth it ?  does it really make it   more secure ?  look at the dvds.  dvds don't use trusted hardware. as for whether it is worth it
column3: that  depends entirely on what its worth to secure your software.  cheers
column4: ben.  --  http://www.apache-ssl.org/ben.html       http://www.thebunker.net/  "there is no limit to what a man can do or how far he can go if he doesn't mind who gets the credit." - robert woodruff

column4: richard kimber wrote:   on mon
column5: 2 sep 2002 13:20:46 -0700 (pdt)  bart schaefer  wrote:     if you're using "fetchmail --mda spamassassin" or the equivlent
column6: then   this change means your current setup will no longer work.     oh well
column7: i guess there are other anti-spam options out there.  well
column8: (a) you don't have to upgrade
column9: and (b) what you are doing has never been safe in the first place because spamassassin 2.31-and-before doesn't do any kind of file locking while it writes to the mailbox and doesn't promise to return the proper failure code on disk-full conditions
column10: etc.  if you're still willing to live with (b)
column11: all you need is a little shell script to run spamassassin:  ---------- #!/bin/sh # call this file "spamassassin-wrapper" and chmod +x it { echo "from $1 `date`" sed -e '1{/^from /d;}' | spamassassin echo '' }  $mail ----------  and then use  fetchmail --mda 'spamassassin-wrapper %f'  and you should be all set.    ------------------------------------------------------- this sf.net email is sponsored by: osdn - tired of that same old cell phone?  get a new here for free! https://www.inphonic.com/r.asp?r=sourceforge1&refcode1=vs3390 _______________________________________________ spamassassin-talk mailing list spamassassin-talk@lists.sourceforge.net https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/spamassassin-talk

column2: thank you lars for your reply to my query.   sa doesnt do any of these. it is probably a function of whatever scanning system/mda  you're using (amavis

column2: "kerry nice" said:   what about some reality check rules.  yeah
column3: you can pack in lots of things  into the header to try and get some negative points
column4: but do they all make  sense in combination.  can you have a pine message id in the same header  with an outlook express one or a mutt user-agent?  yes
column5: this is a big bonus of meta rules (new in 2.40); we can now e.g. check for an outlook-style forwarded message
column6: and not give it negative points unless it contains other signs of being from outlook.   i think the headers should be paid special attention to.  the message  content of something from the ny times or lockergnome might look spammy
column7: but  usually they don't forge or fake anything in the header.  tone down the  negative scores and ding them extra for any obvious forgeries.  when we get more (good) "nice" tests
column8: the ga will assign lower scores to them.  i think the current problem is that there are very few really good nice tests in the current rulebase
column9: and lots of +ve tests that those newsletters hit
column10: giving the ga a big problem to solve.  --j.   ------------------------------------------------------- this sf.net email is sponsored by: osdn - tired of that same old cell phone?  get a new here for free! https://www.inphonic.com/r.asp?r=sourceforge1&refcode1=vs3390 _______________________________________________ spamassassin-talk mailing list spamassassin-talk@lists.sourceforge.net https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/spamassassin-talk

column5: matt sergeant wrote:  can anyone out there who uses sa with lotus notes users help us figure   out what to tell customers to do when they've got emails coming in with   spam identifying headers? we've been told that notes has no way to   handle extra headers

column2: on saturday 07 september 2002 23:22 cet daniel quinlan wrote:  craig hughes  writes:   how about configuring sa to set precendence to "low" for spam   messages
column3: then filter on that -- no real human i've ever seen has   actually set precendence to low on real mail.   assuming there isn't a better way for lotus notes users
column4: we could  create a "precedence: spam" convention.  the only two precedence:  headers i've seen (aside from one or two odd messages) are "bulk" and  "list".  adding a "spam" header makes sense given the convention.  i'd suggest using precedence: junk. albeit it's no standard header does most  software already recognize it. courier eg. doesn't send auto-replies to  mails with the precedence bulk or junk. i think outlook does handle these  special
column5: too. [1] says: | autoresponses should always contain the header |          precedence: junk | notice the spelling of "prec-e-dence". in particular
column6: count the number of | n:s (and a:s and s:es
column7: if you're totally agraphic and/or from the united | states). this will prevent well-tempered mail programs from generating | bounce messages for these. if the recipient can't be reached
column8: the | autoresponder message is simply discarded.  | [...] | (for what it's worth
column9: the meaning of the precedence header in practice is | that it affects sendmail so that messages identified as less important get | moved back in the queue under high load. [...])  [...]  malte  [1] moronic mail autoresponders (a faq from hell): http://www.ling.helsinki.fi/users/reriksso/mail/autoresponder-faq.html --  --- coding is art. --      ------------------------------------------------------- this sf.net email is sponsored by: osdn - tired of that same old cell phone?  get a new here for free! https://www.inphonic.com/r.asp?r=sourceforge1&refcode1=vs3390 _______________________________________________ spamassassin-talk mailing list spamassassin-talk@lists.sourceforge.net https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/spamassassin-talk

on wednesday 11 september 2002 16:19 cet justin mason wrote:  malte s. stretz said: [...]   i think we should even add new (ga'd) rules to 2.4x (and/or remove old   ones) and tag a new 2.50 only if we have a bunch of features worth a   "dangerous" big update. i'd say: yes
column3: you should expect 2.42 and also   2.43+ (but update to 2.41 now).   i would think adding new rules to
column4: or removing broken rules from
column5: 2.4x  would require some discussion first.  but new ga'd scores are definitely  worth putting in
column6: as the ones there are too wild.  i think my mail wasn't very clear ;-) my point was that we should continue  releasing new rules and removing broken ones (all based on discussions on  this list of course) in the 2.4 branch instead of creating a new 2.5 branch  everytime we have a bunch of new rules.  a new branch should be openend only if (big) new features are introduced  (eg. bayes) or the interface has changed (spam_level_char=x). as the rules  are under fluent development
column7: the user has to update quite regularly. but  currently he couldn't be shure if the new release will break anything in  his setup (like -f going away). so if we say "the branches are stable to  the outside and just improved under the surface but you have to watch out  when you update to a new minor version number"
column8: users and sysadmins could  be less reluctant to update.  all just imho :o) malte  p.s.: i'll be away from my box and my mail account for one week
column9: starting  tomorrow. so happy coding for the next week :-)  --  --- coding is art. --

column2: this is not directly spamassassin related
column3: but more of a general dealing-with-spam issue.  what is the best way to deal with spam during the smtp transaction? there are domains and addresses that i know are spam at the 'mail from' and can deal with at the smtp level. i have been
column4: and i think most people
column5: respond with a 5.7.1 code
column6: a "permanent" error. that pretty much means
column7: "don't bother to try from that address again
column8: you'll get the same error." people often add cathartic messages to accompany the 550 like
column9: "spammers must die."  but this might not be the best way to go. you are telling the spammers that you are on to them. this may cause them to try other methods to get around your blocks. is it perhaps better to blackhole the mail? that is
column10: act like everything is ok during the smtp transaction
column11: but then just drop the mail into the bitbucket. column2: op 12-09-2002 00:35 schreef ellen clary (ellen@dgi.com):   then there is a third possibility. instead of returning a 550 code  indicating you're on to the spammer
column3: fake a 5.1.1 response which is  saying "mailbox does not exist." this would be in the hopes that some  spammers out there actually remove names reported as non-existent from  their lists. i know
column4: a slim hope
column5: but even if only a few do
column6: it can  lower the incidence.    they don't
column7: i can guarantee that.  quite a few spamtraps nowadays  operate by 5nn'ing for 6 months in the hope of getting legit mailers  to remove bouncing addrs from lists;  then after 6 months
column8: they just  spamtrap all incoming mail to those addrs.  (unfortunately a lot of  legit mailers don't bother cleaning their lists either.)  most spammers don't check reply codes at all
column9: they just send out as many mails as their system will hold without checking for any confirmation.  a trick to lower spam reception was dicussed on the postfix mailing list some time ago: answer all incoming mail with a 4xx temporary error code when it is offered the first time
column10: and accept it the second time. apparently most mass-emailers don't even try to deliver a second time.    ------------------------------------------------------- this sf.net email is sponsored by:thinkgeek welcome to geek heaven. http://thinkgeek.com/sf _______________________________________________ spamassassin-talk mailing list spamassassin-talk@lists.sourceforge.net https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/spamassassin-talk

column5: carlo@alinoe.com wrote:  so... it seems to me that they do clean up  their lists
column6: but only when a spam fails to  deliver - or can't they detect that?    what do spammers do with email addresses in  their database that are undeliverable for a  few years?  do they still continue to spam  them?  well
column7: here's my semi-coherent rant for the moment.  ;)  i have 3100 spamtraps on my machine (you can multiply that by each domain if you really want to).  the vast majority (all but
column8: say
column9: 10) have never ever existed.  yet
column10: spammers would semi-continuously connect
column11: try to deliver mail to 40 of them
column12: disconnect
column13: connect again
column14: try delivering to 40 more...  over and over
column15: they kept getting "user unknown" until i got around to making them spamtraps.  so my evidence would suggest that it depends who you're dealing with. :) if your "business" is to sell address lists to people who would then spam
column16: it's in your best interest to never clean your list.  therefore you can say "10 million email addresses" and not technically be lying
column17: even if the majority of them don't work.  if you're a spammer
column18: you'd want to know who doesn't actually exist
column19: but then again you don't really care: you probably want to relay through someone so it's harder to trace you
column20: if you could you'd send to every email address available
column21: you don't want to setup a valid bounce address because again it's easy to trace you.  so i would say this
column22: if you technically spam people but actually think you're running a legit service
column23: you probably really do have a way of opting out (even though the user didn't opt in) and you probably don't relay
column24: and you probably pay attention to bounces.  everyone else doesn't really care.   that's my view anyway. :)  --  randomly generated tagline: "now you can do that thing with your hands... it's ok." - prof. farr

column2: -----original message-----  from: carlo@alinoe.com [mailto:carlo@alinoe.com]  sent: 13 september 2002 14:21  to: spamassassin-talk@example.sourceforge.net  subject: [satalk] getting yourself removed from spam lists   i get the feeling that the spammers never  remove emails from their lists.  correct...   on the other hand
column3: that doesn't make sense:  wouldn't they get worried about their millions  of spams being wasted?  don't they want *some*  prove that they indeed *reach* people somehow?  no
column4: they only have to prove that they send several million emails to 'potential clients' to get their money.  i don't think they even care much about bounces.  they're con-artists
column5: why should they care about proving they actually reached people?    so... it seems to me that they do clean up  their lists
column6: but only when a spam fails to  deliver - or can't they detect that?  most of the time the bounce goes to some poor soul who has nothing to do with the spammer.   what do spammers do with email addresses in  their database that are undeliverable for a  few years?  do they still continue to spam  them?  yes.  tony   ------------------------------------------------------- this sf.net email is sponsored by:thinkgeek welcome to geek heaven. http://thinkgeek.com/sf _______________________________________________ spamassassin-talk mailing list spamassassin-talk@lists.sourceforge.net https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/spamassassin-talk

column2: this may be a little off topic but thought people here would have a better response to this elsewhere.  i have setup two mx records (mail and bmail) for my mail server. the one i gave a 10 (bmail) the other a 20 (mail).  bmail(10) i gave a 10 because i want all mail to go through this server to be scanned for spam and viruses and then relayed to the mail(20) server for delivery.  as i understand it
column3: dns a records are used in a rotating fashion for load balancing
column4: but dns mx records are used in order or prority
column5: meaning the 10 before the 20 and only 20 if the 10 isn't available.  but only some of the mail is actually being scanned which leads me to believe that not all of the mail is actually hitting that box and the 10 never goes down. why? have i got something confused here?  thanks

column2: on fri
column3: sep 13
column5: vernon wrote:  as i understand it
column6: dns a records are used in a rotating fashion for load  balancing
column7: but dns mx records are used in order or prority
column8: meaning the 10  before the 20 and only 20 if the 10 isn't available.  that's the theory
column9: yes.   but only some of the mail is actually being scanned which leads me to  believe that not all of the mail is actually hitting that box and the 10  never goes down. why? have i got something confused here?  no
column10: but either due to some technical glitch
column11: or downright just wanting to do so
column12: people send to the secondary.  it's a semi-usual spammer trick actually to bypass the main server and send directly to a secondary since it will either have less filtering
column13: or be "trusted"
column14: or ...  mx records in the mail world are all explained in rfc 2821
column15: section 5:  [...]    multiple mx records contain a preference indication that must be used    in sorting (see below).  lower numbers are more preferred than higher    ones.  if there are multiple destinations with the same preference    and there is no clear reason to favor one (e.g.
column16: by recognition of an    easily-reached address)
column17: then the sender-smtp must randomize them to    spread the load across multiple mail exchangers for a specific    organization. [...]    if it determines that it should relay the message without rewriting    the address
column18: it must sort the mx records to determine candidates for    delivery.  the records are first ordered by preference
column19: with the    lowest-numbered records being most preferred.  the relay host must    then inspect the list for any of the names or addresses by which it    might be known in mail transactions.  if a matching record is found
column20: all records at that preference level and higher-numbered ones must be    discarded from consideration.  if there are no records left at that    point
column21: it is an error condition
column22: and the message must be returned as    undeliverable.  if records do remain
column23: they should be tried
column24: best    preference first
column25: as described above.  --  randomly generated tagline: "now let's say i like sheep...  and now let's say i take the sheep to a   christmas party..."               - bob golub

column4: vernon wrote:    but only some of the mail is actually being scanned which leads me to  believe that not all of the mail is actually hitting that box and the 10  never goes down. why? have i got something confused here?   sending mail directly to a backup mail server in the hopes that it has less stringent spam scanning is a common spammer trick.  --  jason kohles                                 jkohles@redhat.com senior engineer                 red hat professional consulting    ------------------------------------------------------- this sf.net email is sponsored by:thinkgeek welcome to geek heaven. http://thinkgeek.com/sf _______________________________________________ spamassassin-talk mailing list spamassassin-talk@lists.sourceforge.net https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/spamassassin-talk

column5: justin mason wrote:  it's probably that razor needs to be "razor-register"'d for each user.  try creating a world-writable "home dir" for razor and dcc et al to store  their files in; that way spamd will share the razor server info etc.  between all users.  uh
column6: no
column7: you don't want to make it world-writable.  world-readable.   then use "spamd -h /path/to/world/writeable/dir" .  just remember that the .razor and whatever dcc uses needs to be world-readable as well.  the solution is then to make a world-writable log file for at least razor.  i like symlinking /dev/null myself.   imo this is more efficient than using "spamd -h"
column8: which will use each  user's own home dir for this data
column9: but it's a matter of opinion ;)  efficient?  probably (depends on the user base)
column10: but it also takes the control away from the user (which may or may not be a good thing
column11: depending again on the user base...)  --  randomly generated tagline: "what's funny?  i'd like to know.  send me some e-mail." - prof. farr

column2: jm@jmason.org (justin mason) writes:     date_in_past_48_96    spam_phrase_00_01    spam_phrase_01_02    spam_phrase_02_03    spam_phrase_03_05    spam_phrase_05_08   i was thinking of just removing those particular rules
column3: but keeping the  other entries in the range
column4: since they're proving too "noisy" to be  effective.  but i'd be willing to keep those ones in
column5: all the same.  what  do you think?  matt/craig
column6: thoughts?  i think i could handle commenting out the lowest spam_phrase_xx_yy scores.  if the ga could handle this sort of thing so they'd automatically be zeroed
column7: i'd feel better since the ranges could change next time the phrase list is regenerated or the algorithm tweaked.  i think we need to understand why date_in_past_48_96 is so low before we remove it.  the two rules on either side perform quite well.   and here are the rules that seem like they should be better or should  be recoverable:     from_missing    gappy_text    invalid_msgid    mime_null_block    subj_missing   well
column8: i don't like subj_missing
column9: i reckon there's a world of mails from  cron jobs (e.g.) which hit it.  okay
column10: drop subj_missing.   but
column11: yes
column12: the others for sure should be recoverable
column13: and i'm sure there's  more.  probably a few
column14: those seemed like the best prospects to me.   btw do you agree with the proposed methodology (ie. remove the rules and  bugzilla each one?)  i only want a bugzilla ticket for each one if people are okay with quick wontfix closes on the ones deemed unworthy of recovery.  if you could put the stats for each rule in the ticket somehow (should be automatable with email at the very least)
column15: it would help.  dan
