column2: on mon
column4: justin mason wrote:   simon matthews said:     procmail 3.21 is reliable as long as none of the recipies fails. i was    hoping to resolve the triplets.txt problem and thus avoid the procmail    "^rom" problem.     i doubt it's related
column5: actually -- the "triplets" stuff is in a totally  unrelated area of code.  the procmail bug happens when the filter program does something that  procmail doesn't expect.  exactly what that something is
column6: hasn't been confirmed by anyone on the procmail list.  it might be exiting with a nonzero status
column7: or it might be producing output on the standard error
column8: or it might be something else entirely.  so simon is attempting to get sa to run flawlessly
column9: because then it can't tickle the procmail bug.  this isn't a fix
column10: it's a band-aid
column11: but because he apparently doesn't have the option of installing a newer procmail ...

column2: jm@jmason.org (justin mason) writes:   folks who've been hacking on the dnsbls: would it be worthwhile commenting  this in head
column3: seeing as it only gets .77 anyway?    sounds like the (a) broken server and (b) low hitrate combine to make it  not-so-useful imo.  no
column4: in my opinion
column5: it's purely a bug in sa (or the libraries we use
column6: which is the same thing) that we don't handle outages of network services better.  the rule is useful and it does help reduce spam
column7: we should keep it.  i have a feeling the dnsbl rules will cluster a bit more heavily around the 1.0 to 2.0 range once we start using the new ga on them.  also
column8: 0.77 was a slightly conservative number.  since i didn't have real-time data
column9: i typically used the lower or median number of different periods (most recent month
column10: two months
column11: six months)
column12: depending on the trend of the period data (better performance for recent messages - favor recent scores
column13: worse performance for recent messages - favor lowest scores
column14: never pick the highest number unless the rule was very accurate and the highest number was for the most recent data).  dan

column2: matt kettler said:  ok
column3: first
column4: the important stuff. happy birthday justin (a lil late
column5: but  oh well)  cheers!   a 13% miss ratio on the spam corpus at 5.0 seems awfully high
column6: although   that nice low fp percentage is quite nice
column7: as is the narrow-in of average   fp/fn scores compared to 2.40.  as dan said -- it's a hard corpus
column8: made harder without the spamtrap data.  also -- and this is an important point -- those measurements can't be directly compared
column9: because i changed the methodology.  in 2.40 the scores were evolved on the entire corpus
column10: then evaluated using that corpus; ie. there was no "blind" testing
column11: and the scores could overfit and still provide good statistics.  in 2.42
column12: they're evaluated "blind"
column13: on a totally unseen set of messages
column14: so those figures would be a lot more accurate for real-world use.  --j.

column2: "michael moncur" said:   my corpus is about 50% spamtrap spam at any given time. let me know if i  should leave that out next time
column3: i do keep it separate. my spamtraps are  pretty clean of viruses and bounce messages most of the time.  imo spamtrap data that's well-cleaned and monitored is fine.  to my mind there's 3 types of spamtraps:    1. old user addresses
column4: recycled into spamtraps when the user closes     the account    2. old user addresses
column5: recycled into spamtraps several months after the     user closes the account
column6: scanned for newsletters
column7: unsubscribed     from them etc.    3. real spamtrap addresses to trap website crawlers.  the latter 2 are the most effective
column8: but #1 is a real pita; it takes lots of maintainance to avoid ham getting in there.  some of my spamtrap data had a few 1's contributed by isps
column9: and i hadn't spent enough time sifting for legit mail that was slipping through.  so i felt better leaving them out for this run
column10: apart from what i'd hand-cleaned.  --j.

column2: http://www.hughes-family.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=1012      ------- additional comments from easmith@beatrice.rutgers.edu  2002-09-21 16:41 ------- i like this idea
column3: but from my reading - part of my dissertation research - on gas (or
column4: in this case
column5: more precisely "evolutionary programming"
column6: since the parameters are non-binary and the major operator is mutation
column7: not crossover)
column8: you do need to keep in mind that the more interactions there are between different variables
column9: the better-tweaked the ga/ea will need to be
column10: especially to avoid local optima (which may have been the problem with the suspiciously-high "anti-ratware" user_agent scores). from past results
column11: what's needed are one or more of the below:         a. determine mutational parameters by adapted-scores themselves
column12: with variation on a per-original score basis; ideally
column13: allow            for having "correlated" mutations - in other words
column14: have a            mechanism in place for trying out changes to a bunch of scores at            once
column15: with them all moving about the same amount (albeit possibly            in different directions) - one means to do this is found in the            "evolutionary strategies" of schwefel;         b. adapt the probability of a mutation taking place depending on how            well previous mutation tries have done - if more than about a            fifth of the new "individuals" are doing about as well as
column16: or            better than
column17: the parental generation
column18: then mutate more            parameters; if less than a fifth of them are doing about as well            as
column19: or better than
column20: the parental generation
column21: then mutate less            parameters.          -allen    ------- you are receiving this mail because: ------- you are the assignee for the bug
column22: or are watching the assignee.   ------------------------------------------------------- this sf.net email is sponsored by:thinkgeek welcome to geek heaven. http://thinkgeek.com/sf _______________________________________________ spamassassin-devel mailing list spamassassin-devel@lists.sourceforge.net https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/spamassassin-devel

column2: this is just an semi-educated guess - if i'm wrong
column3: someone please correct me!  spamd setuid's to the user running spamc. since you're calling spamc from a global procmailrc file
column4: it's being run as root (most likely). if called as root
column5: spamd won't open user_prefs files.  from the spamc man page:         -u username            this argument has been semi-obsoleted.  to have spamd use            per-user-config files
column6: run spamc as the user whose config            files spamd should load.  if you're running spamc as some            other user though (eg. root
column7: mail
column8: nobody
column9: cyrus
column10: etc.)            then you can still use this flag.   the solution is to set dropprivs=yes in /etc/procmailrc
column11: just before running spamc. from the procmailrc man page:         dropprivs   if set to `yes' procmail will drop all privileges                    it might have had (suid or sgid).  this  is  only                    useful  if  you  want  to guarantee that the bottom                    half of the /etc/procmailrc file is executed on                    behalf of the recipient.   i hope that helps
column12: and i also hope it's right!  st-   | -----original message----- | from: spamassassin-talk-admin@example.sourceforge.net | [mailto:spamassassin-talk-admin@lists.sourceforge.net]on behalf of | cheryl l. southard | sent: tuesday

column2: on sun
column3: sep 22
column5: justin mason wrote:  i seem to be getting a *lot* of spam relayed via these guys recently.  can others confirm this?    if it's the case
column6: i'll come up with a forged-hostname test for it.  i do get some from them
column7: typically some dsl.telesp.net.br host:  % grep -c telesp.net.br *| sort -rn spammers-2002-09:59 spammers-2002-08:64 spammers-2002-07:23 spammers-2002-06:13 spammers-2002-05:4 spammers-2002-04:2  definitely increasing per month.  percentage-wise:  2002-09 has 1212 spams in it
column8: so 59/1212 is about 4.8%.  last month was 3.6%.  --  randomly generated tagline: i don't believe i've ever cuddled my elses.               -- larry wall in

column2: jm@jmason.org (justin mason) writes:   yes -- 50% of the entire set for training and 50% for evaluation.  once you've settled on the final method for any one release
column3: why not use 100% of the data for a final run?   dan

column2: justin mason wrote:   interestingly
column3: some of these seem (apparently) to be encrypted versions of  the recipient email address.  to see this
column4: rot13 yr address and grep your  spam archive.  there'll be at least 1 hit.  theo van dinter  writes:   hmmm.  i'm surprised at these results
column5: especially since i should be  seeing some false positives...  not a lot of matches though. :(  still worthwhile -- 1.257% is not that bad.  :-)  my results:    overall%   spam% nonspam%     s/o    rank   score  name     11774     4079     7695    0.35    0.00    0.00  (all messages)   100.000   34.644   65.356    0.35    0.00    0.00  (all messages as %)     0.195    0.564    0.000    1.00    0.75    1.00  t_rot13_email_3     0.161    0.466    0.000    1.00    0.73    1.00  t_rot13_email_2     0.161    0.466    0.000    1.00    0.73    1.00  t_rot13_email  the interesting thing is that these hits all seem to be rot13 versions of the to: address.  if we ever start getting fps (or if anyone is worried)
column6: we could make it an eval test for rot13 of the to: address (turning non-word characters into "." characters in the regular expression).  at the same time
column7: it might be worth testing for username in html comments.  i found some  types in html comments
column8: but i haven't seen enough hits so far to bother (however
column9: i did add a really good test for email addresses in comments).  dan

column3: thankfully.  i don't want to see any of that stuff in there if it acn be avoided
column4: as different perl versions jsut vary so much in that stuff.  2. perl has no concept of where the rules could be -- unless they're in the perl libdir (/usr/lib/perl5/site_perl/5.x.x/foo).  perl does not know about the existence of /usr/share or /etc.  used to use /usr/lib/perl5 for storing rules
column5: and it was actually *much worse* than it is now. so we need an out-of-band way to tell sa where to find this stuff. that's the problem!  3. try "perl makefile.pl

column2: http://www.hughes-family.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=1046      ------- additional comments from spamassassin-contrib@msquadrat.de  2002-10-03 13:57 -------  i've thought about this and pm_filter needs to die. i've now tried    multiple ways to make it just transparently work on 5.00503 and failed.    if anyone has any bright ideas please jump in.      you see anyone upgrading from the cpan shell will get a failure on the line:         use extutils::makemaker 5.45;    quite some modules from cpan do have a line like this nowadays (i think or  read so somewhere
column3: respectively). and the perl error message is very clear:  "extutils::makemaker version 5.45 required--this is only version 5.4302 at  makefile.pl line 2."     because it never gets chance to reach a "writemakefile" line with a    prereq_pm = { extutils::makemaker = 5.45 } option. so the cpan shell    can't automatically upgrade this module. i cannot think of any way    around this.    i could think of a solution: we could remove the "use" line and add the  version to prereq_pm. after writemakefile() we could add the lines    require extutils::makemaker;    extutils::makemaker-version(5.45);  to do per hand what 'use extutils::makemaker 5.45' does automagically; `perl  makefile.pl` will die with a "uncaught exception from user code:  extutils::makemaker version 5.45 required--this is only version 5.4302 at  makefile.pl line 103." there but we've got a makefile. but i don't know if  cpan will run the make anyway...     to add insult to injury
column4: the pm_filter part gets run during pm_to_blib
column5: which would be fine
column6: except extutils::makemaker doesn't let you write a    my::pm_to_blib - it's non-overridable! so even though we could    potentially copy the 5.45 extutils::install::pm_to_blib code somewhere    into the spamassassin codebase (i tried that first)
column7: we can't cause the    makefile to call our code :-(    we could call the preprocessor on install time. that's not a very clean  approach but could work.    we can also overwrite pm_to_blib in the makefile directly per postamble. we  already have a useless line "pm_to_blib: spamassassin doc/.made" there. adding  some commands in this section gives some make warnings ("makefile:933:  warning: overriding commands for target `pm_to_blib' makefile:877: warning:  ignoring old commands for target `pm_to_blib'") but does work. not a very good  solution either.     so i'm *strongly* against the current use of extutils::makemaker 5.45    usage (if this were an apache project this would be my veto vote)
column8: and    really hope we can find another way.    the "use makemaker::..." error message is imho quite clear
column9: so i think it's ok  to require the user to do a manual update of extutils::makemaker before the sa  installation. but that's just my opinion ;-)    i'll ask on makemaker@perl.org for the best solution. they should know.     ------- you are receiving this mail because: ------- you are on the cc list for the bug

column2: http://www.hughes-family.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=1053             summary: img tag based rules            product: spamassassin            version: unspecified           platform: other         os/version: other             status: new           severity: enhancement           priority: p2          component: eval tests         assignedto: spamassassin-devel@example.sourceforge.net         reportedby: matt@nightrealms.com   inspired by complaints about all-image or mostly-image spam that's getting by sa
column3: i've cooked up three sets of rules that analyze the use of img tags in html: one that looks at the total area of all of the images in the message (t_html_image_area*)
column4: one that looks at the total number of images in the message (t_html_num_imgs*)
column5: and one that looks at the longest total run of consecutive images (t_html_consec_img*).  ===============  the total area of all images is rather easy to compute: inside of html::html_tests()
column6: if an img tag has both the width and height properties
column8: paragraph and linebreak tags
column9: and some whitespace
column10: so there would be a lot of img tags with no plain text (non-whitespace) between them.  so i defined consecutive img tags to be ones with no text between them
column11: and looked at the longest run of consecutive imgs within a message.  this one seems to do pretty good
column12: because in my non-spam corpus there's only a handful of messages with img runs larger than two.    0.450    1.418    0.000    1.00    0.78    0.01  t_html_consec_imgs06   0.232    0.730    0.000    1.00    0.74    0.01  t_html_consec_imgs08   0.205    0.646    0.000    1.00    0.73    0.01  t_html_consec_imgs11   1.813    5.691    0.010    1.00    0.71    0.01  t_html_consec_imgs02   1.019    3.189    0.010    1.00    0.67    0.01  t_html_consec_imgs03   0.768    2.397    0.010    1.00    0.66    0.01  t_html_consec_imgs05   0.053    0.167    0.000    1.00    0.64    0.01  t_html_consec_imgs12   1.006    3.127    0.019    0.99    0.63    0.01  t_html_consec_imgs04   0.483    1.501    0.010    0.99    0.62    0.01  t_html_consec_imgs07   0.020    0.063    0.000    1.00    0.58    0.01  t_html_consec_imgs13   0.020    0.063    0.000    1.00    0.58    0.01  t_html_consec_imgs15   1.032    3.148    0.048    0.98    0.57    0.01  t_html_consec_imgs10   0.199    0.605    0.010    0.98    0.57    0.01  t_html_consec_imgs09   0.013    0.042    0.000    1.00    0.55    0.01  t_html_consec_imgs17   0.013    0.042    0.000    1.00    0.55    0.01  t_html_consec_imgs19   0.007    0.021    0.000    1.00    0.51    0.01  t_html_consec_imgs14   7.080    7.484    6.892    0.52    0.26    0.01  t_html_consec_imgs01   0.000    0.000    0.000    0.00    0.00    0.01  t_html_consec_imgs16   0.000    0.000    0.000    0.00    0.00    0.01  t_html_consec_imgs18  spam % of all rules with s/o  0.90: 22.85%  ==========================  next i'm going to see if there's any meta rules i can make that will reduce the fp rate for low s/o rules.    ------- you are receiving this mail because: ------- you are the assignee for the bug

column2: http://www.hughes-family.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=1054             summary: split up from_ends_in_nums            product: spamassassin            version: unspecified           platform: other         os/version: other             status: new           severity: enhancement           priority: p2          component: rules         assignedto: spamassassin-devel@example.sourceforge.net         reportedby: matt@nightrealms.com   the current from_ends_in_nums triggers on any from where the user name ends in two or more digits.  i think this should be split up into different numbers of trailing digits
column3: so that rules with different s/o ratios can get different scores.  so i've made test rules that look from from names that end with two
column4: three
column5: four
column6: or five digitis
column7: and one for six or more digitis; i also put in a test rule that looks for froms that end in a single digit
column8: just the sake of completeness.  here is what i got:  overall%   spam% nonspam%     s/o    rank   score  name   15113     4797    10316    0.32    0.00    0.00  (all messages) 100.000   31.741   68.259    0.32    0.00    0.00  (all messages as %)   1.244    3.877    0.019    1.00    0.64    0.01  t_from_ends_in_nums6   0.576    1.459    0.165    0.90    0.43    0.01  t_from_ends_in_nums5   4.982   10.694    2.326    0.82    0.38    0.01  t_from_ends_in_nums4   3.434    6.337    2.084    0.75    0.35    0.01  t_from_ends_in_nums3   8.979   12.383    7.396    0.63    0.30    0.01  t_from_ends_in_nums2   8.847    6.817    9.791    0.41    0.22    0.01  t_from_ends_in_nums1  i should note that i get rather bad s/o's for from_ends_in_nums
column9: probably because so much of my corpus is made up of yahoo! groups traffic
column10: which seems to have a lot of users that like sticking numbers at the ends of their names.  here is the normal stats for from_ends_in_nums:    7.024   28.480    2.834    0.91    0.50    0.88  from_ends_in_nums  and my stats:   19.228   34.793   11.991    0.74    0.35    0.88  from_ends_in_nums    ------- you are receiving this mail because: ------- you are the assignee for the bug

kenneth nerhood said:   i too am seeing very weird things with 2.42 and awl.  i  installed a  fresh system
column3: and then ran a bunch of test spam through it (all from the  same user).  all messages should have scored over 15.  the awl kept  adjusting them down so that after about 10 message i had a negative  score.  i'm using spamc/d.  that's exactly what is intended; the idea is that legit senders who habitually score just  5
column4: will eventually get out of "awl hell" after 6-10 messages.  note that running a single spam through "spamassassin -a -t" *will* eventually whitelist the spammer.  but that's why the man page tells you not to do it ;)  --j.   ------------------------------------------------------- this sf.net email is sponsored by:thinkgeek welcome to geek heaven. http://thinkgeek.com/sf _______________________________________________ spamassassin-talk mailing list spamassassin-talk@lists.sourceforge.net https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/spamassassin-talk

column2: on 28 aug 2002
column3: daniel quinlan wrote:   dan kohn  writes:     daniel
column4: it's easy enough for you to change the habeas scores yourself   on your installation.  if habeas fails to live up to its promise to   only license the warrant mark to non-spammers and to place all   violators on the hil
column5: then i have no doubt that justin and craig will   quickly remove us from the next release.  but
column6: you're trying to kill   habeas before it has a chance to show any promise.    i think i've worked on sa enough to understand that i can localize a  score.  i'm just not comfortable with using spamassassin as a vehicle  for drumming up your business at the expense of our user base.  i have to agree here.  if habeas is going to die just because sa does not support it
column7: that's a serious problem with the business model; but that is nobody's problem but habeas's.  a possible solution is for habeas's business model to include some kind of incentive for users of sa to give it the benefit of the doubt.  i have yet to think of an incentive that fits the bill ...  on thu
column9: justin mason wrote:   i don't see a problem supporting it in spamassassin -- but i see dan's  points.      - high score: as far as i can see
column10: that's because spamassassin is      assigning such high scores to legit newsletters these days
column11: and the      habeas mark has to bring it down below that. :(   imo we have to fix      the high-scorers anyway -- no spam ever *needs* to score over 5 in our      scoring system
column12: 5 == tagged anyway.  this is off the topic of the rest of this discussion
column13: but amavisd (in all its incarnations) and mimedefang and several other mta plugins all reject at smtp time messages that scores higher than some threshold (often 10).   if some new release were to start scoring all spam no higher than 5.1
column14: there'd better be _zero_ fps
column15: because all those filters would drop their thresholds to 5.  on thu
column17: michael moncur wrote:   but i agree that there needs to be more focus on eliminating rules that  frequently hit on newsletters. if any newsletters actually use the habeas  mark
column18: that will be one way to help.  newsletters won't use the mark.  habeas is priced way too high -- a factor of at least 20 over what the market will bear
column19: imo -- on a per-message basis for most typical mailing lists (lockergnome
column20: say) to afford it.  on thu
column22: harold hallikainen wrote:   habeus has come up with a very clever way to use existing law to battle  spam. it seems that at some point they could drop the licensing fee to  $1 or less and make all their income off suing the spammers for  copyright infringement.  sorry
column23: that just can't work.  if the habeas mark actually becomes both widespread enough in non-spam
column24: and effectively-enforced enough to be absent from spam
column25: such that
column26: e.g.
column27: sa could assign a positive score to messages that do not have it
column28: then spammers are out of business and habeas has no one to sue.  there's nobody left to charge except the people who want (or are forced against their will because their mail won't get through otherwise) to use the mark.  conversely
column29: if there are enough spammers forging the mark for habeas to make all its income suing them
column30: then the mark is useless for the purpose for which it was designed.  either way it seems to me that
column31: after maybe a couple of lawsuits against real spammers and a lot of cease-and-desist letters to clueless mom&pops
column32: then either (a) they're out of business
column33: (b) they have to sell the rights to use the mark to increasingly questionable senders
column34: or (c) they've both created and monopolized a market for "internet postage stamps" that everybody has to pay them for.  the latter would be quite a coup if they [*] could pull it off -- they do absolutely nothing useful
column35: unless you consider threatening people with lawsuits useful
column36: yet still collect a fee either directly or indirectly from everyone on the internet -- effectively we'll be paying them for the privilege of policing their trademark for them.  i don't believe they'll ever get that far
column37: but i don't particularly want to help them make it.  [*] and i use the term "they" loosely
column38: because the whole company could  consist of one lawyer if it really got to that point.    ------------------------------------------------------- this sf.net email is sponsored by:thinkgeek welcome to geek heaven. http://thinkgeek.com/sf _______________________________________________ spamassassin-talk mailing list spamassassin-talk@lists.sourceforge.net https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/spamassassin-talk

column2: "steve thomas" said:   i created a user (honeypot) and set up an alias to it. then i added a  'hidden' (font color same as background color) link to that address at the  bottom of my html pages. the .procmailrc file for that user is: .....  which will submit the msg to razor then save it locally. i set this up about  a month ago
column3: and haven't received anything other than some viruses (sircam)  on it yet. the viruses are rejected at the mta level
column4: so they're not being  saved/reported to razor.  fwiw
column5: i would now recommend doing this (using a user with a procmailrc) instead of a system alias; more secure
column6: and easier to filter out crud like bounces
column7: virii etc. that render a corpus dirty.  --j.   ------------------------------------------------------- this sf.net email is sponsored by: jabber - the world's fastest growing  real-time communications platform! don't just im. build it in!  http://www.jabber.com/osdn/xim _______________________________________________ spamassassin-talk mailing list spamassassin-talk@lists.sourceforge.net https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/spamassassin-talk

column2: (please feel free to forward this message to other possibly-interested  parties.)  some caveats (in decending order of concern):  1. these messages could end up being falsely (or incorrectly) reported    to razor
column3: dcc
column4: pyzor
column5: etc.  certain rbls too.  i don't think the    results for these distributed tests can be trusted in any way
column6: shape
column7: or form when running over a public corpus.  2. these messages could also be submitted (more than once) to projects    like spamassassin that rely on filtering results submission for ga    tuning and development.  3. spammers could adopt elements of the good messages to throw off    filters.  and
column8: of course
column9: there's always progression in technology    (by both spammers and non-spammers).  the second problem could be alleviated somewhat by adding a nilsimsa signature (or similar) to the mass-check file (the results format used by spamassassin) and giving the message files unique names (md5 or sha-1 of each file).  the third problem doesn't really worry me.  these problems (and perhaps others i have not identified) are unique to spam filtering.  compression corpuses and other performance-related corpuses have their own set of problems
column10: of course.  in other words
column11: i don't think there's any replacement for having multiple independent corpuses.  finding better ways to distribute testing and collate results seems like a more viable long-term solution (and i'm glad we're working on exactly that for spamassassin).  if you're going to seriously work on filter development
column12: building a corpus of 10000-50000 messages (half spam/half non-spam) is not really that much work.  if you don't get enough spam
column13: creating multi-technique spamtraps (web
column14: usenet
column15: replying to spam) is pretty easy.  and who doesn't get thousands of non-spam every week?  ;-)  dan

column14: building a corpus  of 10000-50000 messages (half spam/half non-spam) is not really that  much work.  if you don't get enough spam

column18: was to provide a good
column19: big corpus for academic testing of filter systems; it allows results to be compared between filters using a known corpus.  for spamassassin development
column20: everyone has to maintain their own corpus.  --j.

column2: i'm not sure if this is really a razor problem/issue or a sendmail problem. here's the scenario... my mail server is a 150mhz pc funning freebsd 4.4. ordinarily
column3: the machine is quite idle; it supports my wife's web site with apache server running on it and a few other services (jabber
column4: etc). between the various members of our family
column5: we get a fair amount of email coming in (mailing lists
column6: etc). on occasion
column7: our dsl-based isp dies for a number of hours. when we get a reconnection to the internet
column8: i get a huge flow of emails coming in which are then filtered via razor. as a result
column9: i will sometimes see over 20+ sendmail processes running at the same time after such an occasion. the machine is then really slow.  i noticed that my /etc/procmailrc file had had no arguments associated with the call to razor-check. there was something in the log
column10: though
column11: to make me suspicious that it was possibly not seeing all my razor files. so i have just added "-home /etc/razor" as an argument. i haven't had any down time since then so i cannot comment on whether this change has sped up my razor processing a noticable amount. (this paragraph may be an aside to my real problem
column12: the first paragraph above; but i thought i should be complete in my description.)  at any rate
column13: has anyone else suffered from a backlog of email processing creating lots and lots of sendmail processes?  is there
column14: perhaps
column15: a way to limit the number of sendmail processes?  any ideas would be welcome.  thanks
column16: joe --- joe berry joe@topshot.com aim "joe topshot" yahoo msgr "joetopshot" jabber "joetopshot@topshot.com" baltimore

column2: see your /etc/sendmail.cf file
column3: there are a number of methods for limiting the number of concurrent sendmail processes

column6: you will see what you need...  regards

column2: the following was personal correspondence between two people.  i can't fathom how razor thinks it is spam:    we are struggling with the decisions related to wether or not to  go ahead with our plans to purchase an ocr and forms  scanning solution.   an outside consultant mentioned that he had heard that not to  long ago you folks were considering implementing ocr  technology to reduce data entry costs and improve efficiency.  if you could let us know if you did move foreward with any  plans in that direction it would be of great help to us. may i ask  what initialy prompted you to consider ocr? did you decide it  could help your compamy? what software did you go with?  would you recomend we take a look at it?  at present we are still planning to continue our research until  we decide which ocr system best suits our needs
column3: then  implement it quickly.   if you are just starting to consider this  technology feel free to stay in touch. we will let you know what  we decide on and if it works for us.   if you cannot advise on this please forward this e-mail to the  proper individual in your company who might be able to help with  this.  thanks

column13: for those of you still using elm or other non-gui     clients.  i don't have time to post it as text.       the "spam count" is the total of all spam detected by the various  filters.       jammed is a custom phrase ranking system.     razored is razor v2.     bayesian filter is based off of paul graham's work (statistical     probability)
column14: using a corpus of 4000 non-spam and 2000 spam messages.             spam statistics           date spam count jammed razored blacklisted trollbox bayesian           2002-08-27 370 145    (39.19%) 181    (48.92%) 79    (21.35%) 120   (32.43%) 275    (74.32%)           2002-08-28 397 106    (26.70%) 126    (31.74%) 163    (41.06%) 136   (34.26%) 320    (80.60%)           2002-08-29 346 154    (44.51%) 146    (42.20%) 78    (22.54%) 101   (29.19%) 261    (75.43%)           2002-08-30 366 163    (44.54%) 166    (45.36%) 65    (17.76%) 138   (37.70%) 272    (74.32%)           2002-08-31 282 211    (74.82%) 133    (47.16%) 27    ( 9.57%) 132   (46.81%) 256    (90.78%)           2002-09-01 220 127    (57.73%) 125    (56.82%) 22    (10.00%) 91   (41.36%) 157    (71.36%)           2002-09-02 166 86    (51.81%) 77    (46.39%) 22    (13.25%) 64   (38.55%) 123    (74.10%)               -------------------------------------------------------   this sf.net email is sponsored by: osdn - tired of that same old   cell phone? column2: it's a permissions issue on the razor log file.  spamassassin runs setuid  to the user to whom mail is being delivered.  you'll need to make the razor log file world writable.  on mon

column2: "fox" said:   before or after i whitelisted all the legit mailing lists that razor is  tagging?  i had one false positive in the last four days.  razor tagged some  guys person-to-person message because he used an ostrich-in-your-face jpeg  that is probably pretty popular on the net
column3: and -lm 4 means any single  attachment in a message that is razored
column4: razors the whole message
column5: if i  understand it correctly.  razor folks: is -lm documented anywhere?   btw
column6: i notice all my *.conf files in ~/.razor use "lm = 4" by default anyway.   no
column7: i am not keeping official tally of false positives.  i need to write a  html interface to do it
column8: and then it would be easy.  i imagine you want  false positive rate per filter.  i will work on it tomorrow
column9: and maybe in a  week i will have some stats for false positives.  yeah
column10: that'd be cool -- much appreciated!   comparing text classifiers like spam filters
column11: without tracking fps
column12: is not good.   after all
column13: "cat  /dev/null" gets a 100% hit rate
column14: but without the fp rate figure of
column15: let's say 90%
column16: you'd never know it was a bad thing to do ;)  --j.

column2: gary funck  [2002-09-18 13:57:00 -0700]:  in my experience
column3: there are spam messages that sneak past spam assassin
column4: that razor will pick up. those are the ones that i'm calling "marginal".  basically
column5: i'm hoping that "the collective" of razor users make a better  judge of spam than any single program like sa can
column6: and therefore i can  benefit from their judgement and get more extensive spam filtering. i've  seen examples of this already
column7: where sa doesn't score the spam high enough  to bounce it
column8: but razor does.  i think perhaps you missed the fact that sa scores are adjustable.  if you want sa to tag all messages listed in razor then you can put this in your ~/.spamassassin/user_prefs file.    score razor_check 10  the default score is 3 and the default threshold needed is 5. therefore if you wish to have any razor listed messages tagged by sa then setting a score for any razor listed messages to anything above 5 would be sufficient.  if you are already using sa then the above would be more efficient. otherwise you are running all of the mail through razor twice
column9: once for sa and once again afterward.  if you really want to run razor individually then you should set the 'score razor_check 0' so that sa won't do it and avoid the double network hit.  however
column10: one of the benefits of using sa in combination with razor has been the history of false positive reports in the razor database.  the current score of 3 is hefty
column11: but not enough by itself to tag as spam. but for any real spam is usually enough to push it over the threshold. razor2 addresses the false positive problem but is not yet in as wide of use as razor1.  bob

column2: here is my recipe for maildrop:  # vipul's razor check # log `/usr/bin/razor-check` log "razor-check = $returncode" if ( $returncode == 0 ) {   xfilter "reformail -a'x-razor: spam'"   log "spam caught by vipul's razor"   to "$folders/.spam/" }  i used this with razor version 1.  i'm not sure if it was ever used with razor2.  i am now using spamassassin w/ razor2.  you may wish to remove the log statements once running.  i use both.  spamassassin (sa) catches things that razor does not.  there were enough false positives with razor that i do not trust it alone. after whitelisting all the newsletters i receive
column3: sa w/ razor2 does a very good job.  hth

column2: for everyone's benefit/edification
column3: regardless of razor usage.  --jordan  -----original message----- from: internap backbone status reports [mailto:noc@internap.com] sent: thursday
column4: october 03
column5: 2002 11:30 am to: internap backbone status reports subject: [event notification] uunet north american backbone problems 20021003@06:00 pdt [tix106448] (fwd)   hello
column6: i have just spoken with an uunet technician at 11:23 pdt and he was unable to provide me with any new information regarding the outage.  he did confirm that problems had spread beyond the east coast and are now seen nationwide through out their network.  they are currently working with their hardware vendor to try and isolate the issue.  a large number of internap's connections to uunet remain shutdown and traffic is being routed over alternate providers.  the scale of this outage is causing a large number of peering points with uunet and other providers to be flooded due to the large traffic shifts.  if you have problems reaching specific sites please send an email to noc@internap.com containing a traceroute and source/destination ip addresses and we will investigate.  if it is possible will will attempt to move specific prefixes onto an alternate provider leaving an internap pnap if that will provide better performance.  regards
column7: andrew  -------------------------------------------------------------------- andrew dul                                 network operations center internap network services                   e-mail: noc@internap.com andrew@internap.com                    206.256.9500 - 1.877.the.inoc  the contents of this email message are confidential and proprietary.  ---------- forwarded message ---------- date: thu
column8: 3 oct 2002 08:51:26 -0700 (pdt) from: andrew dul  subject: [event notification] uunet north american backbone problems     [tix106448]   uunet is currently experiencing a large number of problems in their north american backbone.  internap has been aware of these problems since approx 06:00 pst.  most of the problems appear to be concentrated on the east coast but we have reports of problems from other geographic regions.  this is being tracked under internap ticket 106448 and uunet master ticket 651751.  uunet currently does not have any eta for a fix for this event.  if you have issues reaching a specific site please send an email to noc@internap.com with a traceroute showing the path which has a problem.  internap has shutdown peerings to uunet is various cities to help reduce the number of problems that customers will experience.  regards

column2: i am somewhat puzzled by a phone call i (or rather the cio at the isp for whom i work) received from an individual claiming to represent cloudmark. the gist of the call was that since we were using razor and checking our mail against the razor servers and that since those servers contain information proprietary to cloudmark
column3: we would [in the near future?] be required to begin paying cloudmark/spamnet $1.00/user per year. i was wondering if anyone else has received such a call?  i am curious as to whether a spammer has begun to try contacting razor users with the above tactic in an effort to get them to stop using razor or whether the open source/community aspect of the razor project is going by the wayside in lieu of a strictly commercial approach (ala brightmail and the likes).  sven    ------------------------------------------------------- this sf.net email is sponsored by:thinkgeek welcome to geek heaven. http://thinkgeek.com/sf _______________________________________________ razor-users mailing list razor-users@lists.sourceforge.net https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/razor-users

column2: hi
column3: i was inspired by a mode of operation supported by vmware. you can have a base disk image shared by multiple virtual machine (vm) instances. that base image is never altered by a vm instance. instead
column4: each vm instance writes changes to its own "redo" log. future hard disk reads from that vm instance incorporate both the base image and the appropriate redo log to present the current disk image for that specific virtual machine.  this is described here (thanks to duane for providing this link on the honeypots mailing list) http://www.vmware.com/support/reference/common/disk_sharing.html  could this basic concept be used to easily make self-fixing client/server applications that efficiently and automatically recover from most attacks
column5: even before those attacks have been discovered? here is what i imagine.  the physical architectures of most production client/server systems are layered. for example
column6: your basic web application might have a web server running apache
column7: connected to an application server running some j2ee or .net business logic
column8: connected to a database server for persistence. the only one of these whose disk image really should evolve over time is the database server
column9: and even here you often put the static rdbms software on one partition and the changeable datafiles on another partition. it is only the partition with the volatile datafiles that must be allowed to change from one boot to the next. other paritions may need to be writable for
column10: say
column11: swap space
column12: but these changes could be eliminated on each reboot.  when someone cracks this system
column13: they will probably change an image that shouldn't be changed. e.g.
column14: they might leverage a buffer overflow in iis or apache to install a trojan or a backdoor on the more exposed web server. but what if the web server ran off a base image
column15: writing changes to a "delta" or "redo" partition? and then what if every night it automatically erased the redo partition and rebooted? the downtime involved for each machine would be minimal
column16: because it is only deleting data - rather than restoring from backup. in a system with redundant web servers for load balancing or high availability
column17: this could be scheduled in a way such that the system is always accessible. this base/redo partition concept could be implemented at the same level as a feature of hardware raid
column18: allowing for greater performance
column19: reliability
column20: and hack resistance. this concept could also be applied to the application servers
column21: and even the database server partitions (except for those partitions which contain the table data files
column22: of course.)  does anyone do this already? or is this a new concept? or has this concept been discussed before and abandoned for some reasons that i don't yet know? i use the physical architecture of a basic web application as an example in this post
column23: but this concept could of course be applied to most server systems. it would allow for the hardware-separation of volatile and non-volatile disk images. it would be analogous to performing nightly ghosting operations
column24: only it would be more efficient and involve less (or no) downtime.  thanks for any opinions
column25: ben

column5: yannick gingras wrote:  this make me wonder about the relative protection of smart cards.  they have   an internal procession unit around 4mhz.  can we consider them as trusted   hardware ?  the ability to ship smart cards periodicaly uppon cashing of a   monthly subscription fee would not raise too much the cost of "renting" the   system.  smart card do their own self encryption.  can they be used to   decrypt data needed by the system ?  the input of the system could me mangled   and the would keep a reference of how long it was in service.    this sounds really feasible but i may be totaly wrong.  i may also be wrong   about the safety of a smart card.      what do you think ?  that's similar to using hard-locks (either the old parallel
column6: or the new usb).  the problem is that that piece of hardware is trustworthy
column7: but the rest of the pc isn't
column8: so a cracker just needs to simulate the lock/smart card
column9: or peek at the executable after the lock has been deactivated.  regards

column2: i did something crudely along those lines for vms vax maybe 13 years ago; there is at least one product that does it for pc though i don't recall its name. it is also handy for cases where you have a cd image of some filesystem (or some other image of a filesystem) that is intrinsically readonly but whose filesystem will not accept (or is not graceful) readonly storage. it is also more or less necessary if you want to work with worm file structures
column3: which are older still. there have been a number of filesystems for those dating back to the early 1980s if not before.  a generic facility of the type you mention is also one way to implement snapshots on top of an existing filesystem. the written information must (obviously!) be seekable so you can provide the illusion that you wrote to the storage. a device level implementation is however perfectly adequate.  it does not
column4: of course
column5: distinguish for you what should have been changed and what should not. if you truly know a device (or perhaps a partition) must not be written
column6: it can be simpler to either return error on writes
column7: or to just return a fake success on writes yet discard the data. (ntfs lives with the latter strategy just fine from my experiments. i have not tried it on extf3 or reiser.)   btw
column8: think about your mention of raid and consider the complexity of writing to raid4 or raid5... i would contend that with cheaper storage these days
column9: it makes little sense to use raid
column10: save for shadowing and possibly striping. those at least do not have the complexity and slowup dangers that higher raid levels have
column11: and there is not a need to save the cost of disk so much where a single disk may hold 200 gigs and up. why not dedicate another whole disk to fault recovery and lose the complexity and slow write (sometimes) of raid?  glenn everhart   -----original message----- from: bmord@icon-nicholson.com [mailto:bmord@icon-nicholson.com] sent: tuesday

column2: scott mackenzie wrote:  there is a software package that is used (or was up through w2k)  on microsloth for this purpose. ghost
column3: or some such. one essentially  "takes a picture" of the machine's proper config
column4: and then upon  schedule or demand replaces the machine's current config with the  proper picture. it essentially over-writes the entire disk drive.  especially good for student access machines at libraries
column5: etc.  and it is pretty common practice in some environments with public  workstations to just wipe and re-install windows machines on a weekly  (or even daily) basis. it's easier than trying to maintain windows.  crispin  --  crispin cowan

column2: the only way to insure a safe key is to use all the storage space in the universe. too big to decrypt.  my point is there will never be a "safe" key. what i would consider is how long does the data need to be protected. if you need to protect the data for longer than 6 months
column3: do not release it to the public. if you are trying to stop the general public (your customer) from coping the data then use what is available on the market. if you want to stop the bootleggers do not release the data to the public.  i have never seen a lock that could not be unlocked. the act of unlocking the key gives away it's secret.  the tougher the lock the more pissed-off your customers will be. take ms-xp for example. only the home user is forced to register. think of the nightmare if business had to register every copy. how many times have we needed to reinstall our laptop os? notice the amount of mac's sold after the xp release. these where mostly home users that converted to mac os.  the new audio cd's that have digital copy protection so not play on my computer. does this stop me from copying the cd? no. however it does make me return them and get my money back.  the more popular the software the more likely it is to be cracked.  jef

column2: simple approxmation to this: make /usr a separate partion
column3: and mount it   read-only:       * the good news: attackers that want to trojan your software have to       reboot
column4: at least.     * the bad news: administrators that want to update your software       have to reboot
column5: at least.  no reboot is required
column6: you just need to remount it:   # mount -o remount
column7: rw /usr  this requires root access
column8: but presumably /usr is safe from non-root users anyway.  only way to disable this is to have the kernel compiled with something that compartmentalizes capabilities (lids/etc on linux for example) or to remove cap_sys_admin with lcap
column9: which would definately require a reboot
column10: and possibly break some other functionatily to boot.  (pun intended.  my apologies.)  -- brian hatch                  "are you expected?"    systems and               "no.  dreaded."    security engineer www.hackinglinuxexposed.com  every message pgp signed

column2: there is a software package that is used (or was up through w2k)  on microsloth for this purpose. ghost
column3: or some such. one essentially  "takes a picture" of the machine's proper config
column4: and then upon  schedule or demand replaces the machine's current config with the  proper picture. it essentially over-writes the entire disk drive.  especially good for student access machines at libraries
column5: etc.  ben mord wrote:      -----original message-----    from: crispin cowan [mailto:crispin@wirex.com]    sent: wednesday
column6: september 04
column7: 2002 5:46 pm    to: ben mord    cc: webappsec securityfocus.com; secprog securityfocus    subject: re: use of base image / delta image for automated recovery from   attacks      i did my dissertation work in this area (optimistic computing) and so was  interested in applying it to the security problem. unfortunately
column8: you hit a  bunch of problems:        a.. when can you "commit" a state as being "good"?  you can't run from  a  redo log forever; the performance and storage penalties accumulate. even  log  structured file systems garbage collect eventually. so you have to commit  sometime. the problem is that if you commit too eagerly
column9: you might commit  corrupted state. if you commit too conservatively
column10: you eat performance and  storage penalties.      b.. what do you do if you discover that there is corrupted state in the  *middle* of your redo log
column11: and you want some of the critical state that  comes after it? you need some way to dig the corruption out of the middle  and save the rest. my dissertation solves this problem
column12: but you have to  re-write everything in my programming language :)  .    c.. just doing this at all imposes substantial performance penalties. i  love vmware
column13: and use it every day (the best $200 i ever spent on software)  .but it is not very fast.    my proposed solution to the first two problems you mention is to be less  ambitious. the idea is that you *never* commit - instead
column14: you simply revert  to base state on reboot. obviously
column15: you can't do this with partitions that  accrue important state
column16: e.g. a partition that stores database table data.  but in your typical web application
column17: most partitions do not accrue important  state. for example
column18: your typical web server or application server could have  their entire state reset back to a known base state during each reboot  without harm.  the advantage of being less ambitious is that we have a quick and easy way  to frustrate certain attacks without rewriting all of our software or  spending lots of money on additional application-specific coding.    the first two problems you describe only occur if we become more ambitious  and try to apply these same techniques to
column19: for example
column20: the database table  partitions
column21: where state changes remain important across reboots. that would  certainly be a nice touch! but as you point out
column22: many problems would have to  be addressed first
column23: and the hardest of these can not be abstracted away from  the particular application. not the least of these is the problem of writing  heuristics for delineating good from malevolent state. that task is roughly  analogous to what antiviral software authors do for a living
column24: only this work  could not be shared across many different systems as it would be specific to  a paritcular application.    the third problem you mention - performance penalty - is an argument for  doing this in hardware
column25: much like hardware raid. another argument for doing  this in hardware is hack resistance. changing the base instance should  require physical access to the console
column26: e.g. by requiring that you first  flip a physical switch on your raid hardware or modify a bios setting. if  the base image can be modified remotely or by software
column27: then you have to  worry about whether an implementation flaw might permit a cracker to modify  the base image remotely.    ben  --      (                                                ______     ))   .-- scott mackenzie; dine' college isd --.   ===---  phone/voice mail:  928-724-6639 ---

column2: -----original message----- from: crispin cowan [mailto:crispin@wirex.com] sent: wednesday
column3: september 04
column4: 2002 7:30 pm to: ben mord cc: webappsec securityfocus.com; secprog securityfocus subject: re: use of base image / delta image for automated recovery from attacks   ben mord wrote:       -----original message-----      *from:* crispin cowan [mailto:crispin@wirex.com]      *sent:* wednesday
column5: september 04
column6: 2002 5:46 pm      *to:* ben mord      *cc:* webappsec securityfocus.com; secprog securityfocus      *subject:* re: use of base image / delta image for automated      recovery from attacks       ben mord wrote:   my proposed solution to the first two problems you mention is to be  less ambitious. the idea is that you *never* commit - instead
column7: you  simply revert to base state on reboot.  ah. in that case
column8: you can use something considerably less powerful than vmware. all you need is a machine configured to boot from cd-rom and use a ram disk for scratch space. numerous linux distros are available that let you boot a stateless but functional system from cd-rom.  but ram is expensive
column9: and the directory structures of many systems (e.g. windows) are not sufficiently organized and standardized to make this combination of bootable cds and ram drives practical. even if you are fortunate enough to be using linux (or another fhs-compliant *nix)
column10: you still can't fit a lot on a cd. its not unusual today to have gigabytes of static multimedia content on the web server. this particular problem can be alleviated somewhat by using dvds
column11: but this is a temporary solution at best which will become outdated quickly as our data requirements grow and hard drives become cheaper.   obviously
column12: you can't do this with partitions that accrue important  state
column13: e.g. a partition that stores database table data.  ... but if you *do* want some state to persist
column14: then you need a mountable writable partition. to protect it
column15: you need some kind of access control management to decide who can do what to the writable partition
column16: blah blah blah ... and before you know it
column17: the security problem starts to look just like it does for conventional servers.  right. this is why you would consolidate all state of any long-term significance on just a couple partitions
column18: and why you would not put static application code on these changeable partitions. fortunately
column19: most large client/server application physical architectures do this anyhow
column20: because these are two fundamentally different kinds of state with two very different sets of administrative
column21: security
column22: raid
column23: and backup requirements. people also tend to do this anyhow because layered logical architectures are popular with the gui at one end
column24: business logic in the middle
column25: and persistence services at the other. this logical architecture maps naturally to a physical architecture that has a static web server
column26: a static application server
column27: and a database server that has static and changeable partitions. (i use the word static versus changeable instead of writeable versus unwritable because the "unchangeable" partitions might be written to for temporary swap space. who knows what windows does internally?)  my point is that there should be a market out there for a hardware raid device that can split designated partitions into a permanent base image partition and a temporary delta image partition
column28: that has some simple but solid security measures to prevent the unauthorized remote modification of base images
column29: and that can be configured to clear the delta image when the server is rebooted. if some vendor wished to implement this
column30: they could then market this as a mechanism to help frustrate broad classes of attack that rely on the permanent modification of system or application files via buffer overflows
column31: platform and middleware bugs
column32: etc. the prevention of unauthorized modification of application data
column33: of course
column34: would not be addressed by this particular product. but there are many other techniques out there to defend application data. but those techniques all assume that your system itself has not been compromised at a lower level
column35: which is where this product could help.  i would have to think that these features would be relatively easy for a hardware raid vendor to implement. (i'm just guessing
column36: of course
column37: with no knowledge of how hardware raid works internally.) if anyone knows of such a product
column38: i'd love to hear about it.  ben

column2: on 5 sep 2002
column3: richard bartlett wrote:  richard
column4: i have a customer who is developing some printer driver code to allow   custom driver settings (n-up
column5: booklet
column6: duplex etc.) to be saved up to the   server to be retrieved by other users.   the data is being written
column7: by a   printer driver (using the logged on users authentication
column8: to a registry   key) hklm\system\currentcontrolset\control\print\environments\windows nt   x86\drivers\version-3\{driver name}\{custom key}\subkey).  let me get this straight; a registry key is loaded from the server onto  the client workstations who can modify it
column9: then write it back onto the  server's own registry - which is not going to use it?   the question is
column10: what are the security risks of allowing users to write   to this key?  the data is string data
column11: in the form of delimited numeric   values.  this data is then retrieved by capable printer drivers and   interpreted.    the risks as i see it are twofold;  (1) the risks of a compromise to the server using this registry key.  i   think this is unlikeley as the server itself does not use this data
column12: only   client pc's do.  unless someone knows a way to travel out of a hive up   the registry bypassing the permissions set using regedt32.  what is the reason to write a registry key to a server if the server  itself is not using it? i don't think you should worry too much about someone travelling out of  the hive
column13: but again
column14: i'm curious as to how the driver actually modifies  the keys on the server.   (2) the risks of a compromise to the client (far more likely).  this   would probably be by a malformed or extremely long string in the key   value
column15: which would presumably lead to either dos or system compromise by   buffer overflow on the client system.  and if the client writes the key back onto the server
column16: yes
column17: there's wide  open for something nasty here. two other things spring to mind;  1) if anyone can modify the key
column18: how do you make sure that two users are  not overwriting the same key
column19: thereby causing undesirable effects. 2) if anyone have permissions to write to the key (and below)
column20: anyone can  create thousands of extra keys under this key
column21: thereby filling up the  registry. the result of such a thing is obvious.  if i got this all wrong
column22: i'd be happy that you clarify a bit more and tell  me where i might have misunderstood.   med venlig hilsen / best regards
column23: -allan jensen  si hoc signum legere potes
column24: operis boni in rebus latinus alacribus et  fructuosis potiri potes!

column2: bryan feir [mailto:bryan@sgl.crestech.ca] wrote:   of course
column3: once one player key was broken
column4: dealing with the rest became  a known plaintext attack
column5: and the rest of the player keys went down like  a row of dominos.  the actual follow-up to the xing player break was more interesting than that.  the mere knowledge of known plaintext (a corresponding input and output) does not necessarily make it trivial to break a properly designed systems and/or algorithm. the primary reason it was easy for css is because the css key was only 40-bits
column6: and thereby easy to break with exhaustive search attacks.  it was only 40-bits (speculated) because of a misunderstanding of the government cryptography export rules at the time.  even more interesting
column7: to me at least
column8: was that soon after the xing player break
column9: people started studying the css algorithm itself.  they rapidly found serious design flaws which left the 40-bit css algorithm with an actual strength of around 23-bits (from memory
column10: and new attacks might have further reduced the strength).  this is another great example showing why proprietary cryptography algorithms should be viewed with the greatest of suspicion.   on tue
column11: sep 03
column13: yannick gingras wrote:  this make me wonder about the relative protection of smart cards. they have   an internal procession unit around 4mhz.  can we consider them as trusted   hardware ?    yes and no.  you can put a limited amount of trust in a smart card. there have been any number of very clever attacks against smartcards (ross anderson in the uk has documented quite a few of these)
column14: and smartcard manufactures are usually one step behind these attacks.  a well designed system assumes that a system smartcard will be completely compromised at some point
column15: giving an adversary all of the secrets contained in the smartcard.  the cryptography industry has developed a variety of techniques that can reduce the impact of a compromise
column16: including unique keys per smartcard and forward security techniques.   luciano rocha [strange@nsk.yi.org] wrote:    the problem is that that piece of hardware is trustworthy
column17: but the rest of  the pc isn't
column18: so a cracker just needs to simulate the lock/smart card
column19: or  peek at the executable after the lock has been deactivated.  going back to the original question
column20: once the encrypted material goes outside the trusted hardware
column21: it is impossible to "unbreakably" protect it.  there may be some mitigation steps you can take
column22: such as the sdmi watermarking
column23: but most schemes to date have been easily broken.    another consideration is the value of what you are trying to protect. while there is no such thing as unbreakable
column24: adding more cost (both in terms of price and hassle-factor) can greatly improve the protection. since you are talking about the use of standard pc workstations
column25: i presume what you are trying to protect is not that valuable.  i'm afraid most security measures don't come for free.   michael mckay  director of software development  mmckay@iscubed.com     information security systems & services inc.    19925 stevens creek blvd. cupertino

column2: on thursday 19 september 2002 16:44
column3: michael mckay wrote:  on tue
column4: sep 03
column6: yannick gingras wrote:   this make me wonder about the relative protection of smart cards.  they have an internal procession unit around 4mhz.  can we consider them as  trusted hardware ?  smartcards do not have fixed clock rates (more often than not) as the iso spec  dictates that they are externally powered and clocked
column7: but smartcards used  for security purposes (usually javacards) have built-in crypto co-processors  that make clock rate irrelevant. 4mhz smartcards can often preform triple-des  faster than general purpose processors clocked at ten times the speed.  that said
column8: clock rate has nothing with how trustworthy a card is. as michael  pointed out
column9: there's something of an arms-race between manufacturers and  attackers which has nothing to do with clock rate
column10: and time and time again  what we've seen is that it's not a question of "is it secure"
column11: it's a  question of "who is it secure from and for how long?" security is rarely a  question of absolutes (despite the often boolean nature of a break)
column12: rather  it's a question of assessing
column13: quantifying
column14: and managing risk. smartcards are  designed to address threats in which the cost of protection cannot exceed the  $1-20 range (depending on the application).  as whether or not they are "trusted hardware"
column15: the question again revolves  around attacker and timeframe. one might expect a bored undergrad ee student  to have more trouble revealing the contents of a pilfered smartcard than
column16: say
column17: a governtment intelligence service. if your goal is to keep undergrad  ees from perpetrating mass fraud in the caffeteria
column18: then a smartcard is  likely "trustworthy" enough for your application. if your aim is to protect  icbm launch codes
column19: then it's probably the wrong tool. in either application
column20: a risk/cost ratio must justify the use of the protection measure in question.  --  alex russell alex@securepipe.com alex@netwindows.org

column2: hi everybody!  i'm writing a web application in java (tomcat + jsp/servlets + database  access with postgresql).  this will be released under the gpl and will eventually be useful as a  framework for other web applications.  the application main focus is e-commerce
column3: but not limited to that.  i would like to use some form of cryptography to protect data on the  database
column4: but i have some problem figuring out the right approach.  above all
column5: how to store passwords and keys in a shared web server.  a problem that i was unable to solve is how to store keys for  encryption/decryption. the api that i'm using is the jca (jdk1.4.x)
column6: and the methods of saving generated keys in keystores fails always.   i can serialize the object
column7: and store in the database
column8: but this is not  the most secure approach: this key is needed to decrypt data in the  database
column9: but the database is accessible from the web application.  assuming that i can find a good and secure place where to store the  database password
column10: i can use a different database with different  user... argh... to complex and doesn't really solve the problem.  where i can found good documentation about this topic?  there is another approach that i would share with the list
column11: something i  thought that can be of bit interest
column12: but probabily wrong and insecure.  after all
column13: i'm a real beginner in secure programming
column14: and i'm here to  learn methods and technics.  first of all
column15: i need a secure way to keep database passwords secure
column16: so  i have to keep them separate from the main server. the right approach  could be using a small java bean application that run as normal user  (not tomcat
column17: so it is not shared with other web services or
column18: worst
column19: the  nobody user)
column20: that has no shell login
column21: but has a default home directory  or a place where it can hold passwords and keys.  the web application could then open an ssl connection (could be done in  the init method at server startup) to get database passwords. the small  bean could check via code signature/rmi/whatever else that the source  is the right one
column22: and handle all the database connections
column23: or give the  db connection/password to the main web application.  in this way
column24: we solve the problem of keeping the keys and passwords in  shared directories
column25: and also
column26: an attacker should get root/bean user  account to read data. this is not perfect
column27: and works only if your  provider gives the opportunity to configure a separated java  application (that means
column28: really
column29: another server running in the  background).  any suggestions?  thank you

column2: forwarded-by: rob windsor  forwarded-by: "dave bruce"  forwarded by: gary williams   a mother had 3 virgin daughters. they were all getting married within a  short time period. because mom was a bit worried about how their sex  life would get started
column3: she made them all promise to send a postcard  from the honeymoon with a few words on how marital sex felt.   the first girl sent a card from hawaii two days after the wedding.  the  card said nothing but "maxwell house".  mom was puzzled at first
column4: but  then went to the kitchen and got out the nescafe jar. it said: "good till  the last drop." mom blushed
column5: but was pleased for her daughter.   the second girl sent the card from vermont a week after the wedding
column6: and the card read: "benson & hedges".  mom now knew to go straight to  her husband's cigarettes
column7: and she read from the benson & hedges pack:  "extra long
column8: king size".  she was again slightly embarrassed but still  happy for her daughter.   the third girl left for her honeymoon in the caribbean.  mom waited for  a week
column9: nothing. another week went by and still nothing.  then after a  whole month
column10: a card finally arrived.  written on it with shaky  handwriting were the words: "british airways".  mom took out her latest  harper's bazaar magazine
column11: flipped through the pages fearing the worst
column12: and finally found the ad for the airline.  the ad said: "three times a  day
column13: seven days a week
column14: both ways."   mom fainted.

column5: 00.html  port san luis
column6: california september 05
column7: 2002  a whale which suddenly breached and crashed into the bow of a fishing boat killed a restaurant owner on board.  jerry tibbs
column9: of bakersfield
column10: california
column11: was aboard his boat
column12: the bbq
column13: when the whale hit and tossed him into the sea five miles off port san luis.  three other fishermen stayed aboard the damaged boat
column14: which was towed to shore by the us coast guard.  tibbs and his three friends were just ending a day fishing for albacore when the accident occurred
column15: authorities said.  tibbs' body was found after a search lasting more than 18 hours coast guard officials said it was the first time they could recall an accident caused by a whale hitting a boat.

column3: 2002  "i'm a tad furry
column4: so animal rights issues come into play."  robin williams
column5: telling entertainment weekly why he won't do  nude scenes in movies.  =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-= johnny u: johnny unitas was the national football league's most valuable player twice - and he led baltimore to victory in "super bowl five." for those of you younger than 30: this was modern football.  the game was played on artificial turf. (richard burkard/ http://www.laughline.com)  announcement: how telling is it that the death of johnny unitas was announced by the baltimore ravens - and not the colts
column6: who now play in indianapolis?  when the colt owners moved out of baltimore years ago
column7: they apparently left all the history books behind. (burkard)  dick disappears: vice president dick cheney remains at an undisclosed location.  the move is for security reasons.  the bush administration is trying to keep him at a safe distance from would-be subpoenas. (alan ray - http://www.araycomedy.com)  noelle nabbed: jeb bush's daughter noelle is in trouble with the law again.  when she was a child
column8: her dad would read her favorite bedtime story.  goldilocks and the three strikes. (ray)

column5: 00.html  by paul crosbie sep 16
column6: 2002  virgin's latest airliner is being revamped after randy passengers discovered a tiny cabin was just the place to join the mile high club.  the  130million airbus 340-600 is fitted with a 5ft x 4ft mother and baby room with a plastic table meant for changing nappies.  but couples keep wrecking it by sneaking in for a quick bonk.  virgin has replaced the table several times even though the plane only came into service a few weeks ago.  it is named claudia nine after sexy model claudia schiffer
column8: who launched it in july.  now virgin bosses have asked airbus to build a stronger table.  at first
column9: german engineers responsible for the jet's interior were baffled by the problem.  the table is designed to take the weight of a mum and baby.  one airbus worker said: "we couldn't work it out. then the penny dropped. it didn't occur to the germans that this might happen. it caused great amusement."  the firm say the cost of strengthening the tables will be about  200.  a virgin spokeswoman said: "those determined to join the mile high club will do so despite the lack of comforts.  "we don't mind couples having a good time but this is not something that we would encourage because of air regulations."  the new airbus is the world's longest airliner
column10: with teasing slogan "mine is bigger than yours". virgin is using it on flights to the far east and the us.

column2: forwarded-by: flower  did you know that you can tell from the skin whether a person is sexually active or not?  1. sex is a beauty treatment. scientific tests find that when woman    make love they produce more of the hormone estrogen
column3: which makes    hair shiny and skin smooth.  2. gentle
column4: relaxed lovemaking reduces your chances of suffering    dermatitis
column5: skin rashes and blemishes. the sweat produced cleanses    the pores and makes your skin glow.  3. lovemaking can burn up those calories you piled on during that    romantic dinner.  4. sex is one of the safest sports you can take up. it stretches    and tones up just about every muscle in the body. it's more enjoyable    than swimming 20 laps
column6: and you don't need special sneakers!  5. sex is an instant cure for mild depression. it releases the body    endorphin into the bloodstream
column7: producing a sense of euphoria and    leaving you with a feeling of well-being.  6. the more sex you have
column8: the more you will be offered. the sexually    active body gives off greater quantities of chemicals called    pheromones.  these subtle sex perfumes drive the opposite sex crazy!  7. sex is the safest tranquilizer in the world. it is 10 times more    effective than valium.  8. kissing each day will keep the dentist away. kissing encourages    saliva to wash food from the teeth and lowers the level of the acid    that causes decay
column9: preventing plaque build-up.  9. sex actually relieves headaches. a lovemaking session can release    the tension that restricts blood vessels in the brain.  10. a lot of lovemaking can unblock a stuffy nose. sex is a national     antihistamine. it can help combat asthma and hay fever.  enjoy sex!

column2: forwarded-by: chris wedgwood  from: bert  01. i was so poor growing up...  if i wasn't a boy...  i'd have had     nothing to play with.  02. a girl phoned me the other day and said
column3: "come on over; nobody's     home."  i went over. nobody was home.  03. during sex
column4: my girlfriend always wants to talk to me.  just the     other night she called me from a hotel  04. one day i came home early from work...  i saw a guy jogging     naked. i said to the guy
column5: "hey buddy
column6: why are you doing that?"  he     said "because you came home early."  05. it's been a rough day. i got up this morning...  put a shirt on     and button fell off.  i picked up my briefcase
column7: and the handle     came off.  i'm afraid to go to the bathroom.  06. i was such an ugly kid...  when i played in the sandbox
column8: the cat     kept covering me up.  07. i could tell my parents hated me.  my bath toys were a toaster and     radio.  08. i was such an ugly baby...  my mother never breast fed me. she     told me that she only liked me as a friend.  09. i'm so ugly...  my father carries around a picture of the kid who     came with his wallet.  10. when i was born
column9: the doctor came into the waiting room and said to     my father
column10: "i'm sorry. we did everything we could
column11: but he pulled     through."  11. i'm so ugly...  my mother had morning sickness...  after i was     born.  12. i remember the time that i was kidnapped and they sent a piece of     my finger to my father.  he said he wanted more proof.  13. once when i was lost
column12: i saw a policeman
column13: and asked him to help me     find my parents. i said to him
column14: "do you think we'll ever find     them?" he said
column15: i don't know kid. there's so many places they can     hide.  14. my wife made me join a bridge club. i jump off next tuesday.  15. i'm so ugly...  i worked in a pet shop
column16: and people kept asking how     big i'd get.  16. i went to see my doctor. "doctor
column17: every morning when i get up and     i look in the mirror...  i feel like throwing up; what's wrong     with me?" he said...  "i don't know but your eyesight is perfect."  17. i went to the doctor because i'd swallowed a bottle of sleeping     pills. my doctor told me to have a few drinks and get some rest.  18. with my old man i got no respect. i asked him
column18: "how can i get my     kite in the air?" he told me to run off a cliff.  19. some dog i got. we call him egypt because in every room he leaves     a pyramid. his favorite bone is in my arm.  last night he went on     the paper four times - three of those times i was reading it.  20. one year they wanted to make me poster boy - for birth control.  21. my uncle's dying wish was to have me sitting in his lap; he was in     the electric chair.
